questions.text: Which enzyme is responsible for generating 'oxygen burst' within neutrophils for killing intracellular bacteria?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3): NADPH Oxidase  
 
  • NADPH oxidase is the enzyme responsible for generating the 'oxygen burst' within neutrophils.
  • This burst involves the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS), such as superoxide anion (O2-) and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), which are crucial for killing intracellular bacteria.
  • NADPH oxidase transfers electrons from NADPH to molecular oxygen, generating superoxide anion in the process.
  • Deficiencies in NADPH oxidase activity lead to impaired bacterial killing and are seen in disorders such as Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD).
* [Extra Edge]: Immunodeficiency Disorder



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 82.

questions.text: Out of the following organelles which play a pivotal role in Apoptosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1): Mitochondria
 
  • Mitochondria play a pivotal role in apoptosis, the process of programmed cell death.
  • Mitochondria release cytochrome c, which activates the intrinsic (mitochondrial) pathway of apoptosis.
  • Cytochrome c interacts with apoptotic protease-activating factor 1 (Apaf-1) and procaspase-9, forming the apoptosome complex that initiates the caspase cascade.
  • This cascade ultimately leads to cell death by activating executioner caspases and initiating the breakdown of cellular components.
* [Extra Edge]: Apoptosis Vs Necrosis


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 45.

questions.text: All of the following enzymes may contribute in generating free oxygen/free radicals within neutrophils for killing intracellular bacteria, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is Option (4) Glutathione Peroxidase 

Glutathione peroxidase is not involved in generating free oxygen radicals within neutrophils for killing intracellular bacteria. Glutathione peroxidase plays a role in reducing hydrogen peroxide and lipid peroxides, thereby protecting cells from oxidative damage. 







Other options
  • Myeloperoxidase combines H202 with Cl- resulting in geneatin of Hypochlorite (HOCl) ion which is a potent bactericidal and kills bacteria. 
  • Fenton's reaction involves the reaction between hydrogen peroxide and ferrous ions to generate hydroxyl radicals (OH·).
  • NADPH oxidase generates superoxide anion (O2-) as part of the respiratory burst in neutrophils.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 82.

questions.text: Most characteristic feature of acute inflammation is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Vasodilatation and Increased vascular permeability 
 
  • Vasodilatation and increased vascular permeability are the most characteristic features of acute inflammation.
  • Vasodilatation leads to increased blood flow to the affected area, resulting in redness and heat.
  • Increased vascular permeability allows the passage of fluid, proteins, and leukocytes from the blood vessels into the surrounding tissues, leading to swelling and edema.
  • These vascular changes are essential for the recruitment of inflammatory cells and the delivery of plasma proteins and immune mediators to the site of injury or infection.
* [Extra Edge]: Acute Inflammation Vs Chronic Inflammation


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 75.

questions.text: All of the following statements about Xanthogranulomatous inflammation are true except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4): Associated with Tuberculosis
 
  • Xanthogranulomatous inflammation is a chronic inflammatory condition characterized by the presence of foam cells, yellow nodules, and multinucleated giant cells.
  • The condition is associated with chronic infections, most commonly involving the urinary tract, such as pyelonephritis or cholecystitis.
  • Xanthogranulomatous inflammation is not specifically associated with tuberculosis. It can occur due to various other bacterial infections.
  • Xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis occurs when chronic urinary obstruction (often by staghorn calculi), together with chronic infection, leads to suppurative destruction of renal tissue.
  • Xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis, the gallbladder has a massively thickened wall and is shrunken, nodular, and chronically inflamed with foci of necrosis and hemorrhage.
     
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 876.

choices.text: Factors X is part of both intrinsic and extrinsic pathways
Extrinsic pathway is activated by contact with negatively charged surfaces
Intrinsic pathway can be activated in vitro
Calcium is required in several steps of coagulation

questions.text: All of the following are true about blood coagulation, except
questions.solution:
• Blood coagulation is a complex process that involves multiple pathways and factors. The intrinsic and extrinsic pathways are two important pathways that lead to the formation of a blood clot. Factor X is a common factor in both pathways, and its activation is essential for the formation of a blood clot. Therefore, option 1 is correct.
  • Option 2 states that the extrinsic pathway is activated by contact with negatively charged surfaces, which is not true. The extrinsic pathway is primarily activated by tissue factor (TF), which is a transmembrane protein present on the surface of cells outside the blood vessels. When there is tissue damage, TF is exposed to the blood, and it activates factor VII, which then activates factor X. Therefore, option 2 is incorrect.
  • Option 3 is true, as the intrinsic pathway can be activated in vitro (outside the body) by contact with artificial surfaces or negatively charged substances.
  • Option 4 is also true, as calcium ions play a crucial role in several steps of blood coagulation, including the activation of factor X and the conversion of prothrombin to thrombin.
  • In summary, all options except option 2 are true about blood coagulation.


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 555,556

questions.text: HbH is associated with:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Deletion of 3 alpha genes 
 
  • HbH (hemoglobin H) disease is caused by the deletion of three alpha genes, resulting in a deficiency of alpha-globin chains.
  • The remaining alpha genes are unable to produce enough alpha-globin chains, leading to the formation of abnormal hemoglobin H (composed of four beta chains) in red blood cells.
  • HbH disease results in chronic hemolytic anemia and can manifest with splenomegaly, jaundice, and bone changes.
  • The deletion of four alpha genes would result in the more severe form, alpha-thalassemia major (also known as hydrops fetalis).

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 648.

choices.text: Normal Platelet count with prolonged bleeding time
Normal Platelet count with normal bleeding time

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Platelet function defects is true:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Normal Platelet count with prolonged bleeding time
 
  • Platelet function defects are disorders characterized by abnormalities in platelet function, leading to impaired clot formation and prolonged bleeding time.
  • Platelet function defect is known as Thrombesthania. 
  • The platelet count in platelet function defects is typically normal, as these disorders primarily affect the function rather than the number of platelets.
  • Prolonged bleeding time, which measures the time it takes for bleeding to stop after a standardized skin incision, is a characteristic finding in platelet function defects.
  • Other laboratory tests, such as platelet aggregation studies, can also be performed to evaluate platelet function. It is important to distinguish platelet function defects from other causes of bleeding disorders, such as platelet count disorders or coagulation factor deficiencies.
  • Platelet function defects refer to conditions in which platelets do not function properly, leading to a prolonged bleeding time. Thrombocytopenia is a condition in which there is a low platelet count, which can also lead to a prolonged bleeding time.
  • Thrombocytosis, on the other hand, is a condition in which there is an excessive number of platelets, but this does not necessarily affect platelet function.
  • Therefore, a normal platelet count with a prolonged bleeding time is indicative of platelet function defects.
  • This can be caused by a number of conditions, including von Willebrand disease, Glanzmann's thrombasthenia, and Bernard-Soulier syndrome, among others.
  • Diagnosis is typically made through a combination of clinical evaluation, bleeding time tests, platelet function assays, and genetic testing.
* [Extra Edge]: Platelet Disorder


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 666.

choices.text: Aggregation with collagen and ADP is normal
Due to GP Ib IX receptor defect

questions.text: Which is not true regarding Bernard soulier syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Ristocetin aggregation is normal
 
  • Bernard-Soulier syndrome is a rare congenital bleeding disorder characterized by a defect in platelet function and decreased platelet adhesion.
  • Ristocetin-induced platelet aggregation is specifically impaired in Bernard-Soulier syndrome.
  • Ristocetin is a medication that induces platelet aggregation by causing the binding of von Willebrand factor (vWF) to platelet surface receptors.
  • In Bernard-Soulier syndrome, the affected platelets lack the glycoprotein Ib-IX-V complex, which is the receptor for vWF, resulting in abnormal platelet-vWF interactions and impaired aggregation.



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 120.

questions.text: Which is the most common/frequently seen antibodies in Antiphospholipid Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4): Anti-beta 2 glycoprotein antibody 
 
  • Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) is an autoimmune disorder characterized by the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies (aPL) and a predisposition to thrombotic events.
  • The most commonly detected antibodies in APS are anti-beta 2 glycoprotein antibodies.
  • Anti-beta 2 glycoprotein antibodies target beta 2 glycoprotein I, a protein that binds to phospholipids on cell surfaces, including those on platelets and endothelial cells.
  • Other commonly seen antibodies in APS include anticardiolipin antibodies and lupus anticoagulant.
  • APS is an autoimmune disorder characterized by:

    1. Presence of one or more antiphospholipid (aPL) autoantibodies
    2. Venous or arterial thromboses, or pregnancy complications such as recurrent miscarriages, unexplained fetal death, and premature birth.
     

* [Extra Edge]: Autoantibodies 


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 128.

questions.text: Which is an exception to an autoimmune disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Sickle Cell Disease
 
  • Sickle cell disease is not an autoimmune disease, but a genetic disorder characterized by the presence of abnormal hemoglobin (hemoglobin S) within red blood cells, inherited in an autosomal recessive manner.
  • Autoimmune diseases result from an abnormal immune response directed against self-antigens, leading to tissue damage and inflammation.
  • In contrast, sickle cell disease is caused by a mutation in the beta-globin gene, leading to the production of abnormal hemoglobin and the formation of sickle-shaped red blood cells.
* [Extra Edge]: Autoimmune Disease


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 641.

questions.text: Necrotizing lymphadenitis is characteristically seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Kikuchi disease 
 
  • Necrotizing lymphadenitis, also known as Kikuchi disease or histiocytic necrotizing lymphadenitis, is a rare benign condition that primarily affects young adults.
  • It is characterized by tender, enlarged lymph nodes, most commonly in the cervical region.
  • Histologically, Kikuchi disease is characterized by necrotizing lymphadenitis with karyorrhexis (fragmentation of the cell nucleus) and abundant histiocytes.
  • The exact etiology of Kikuchi disease is unknown, but it is believed to involve a dysregulated immune response, possibly triggered by viral infections.
  • Kikuchi disease is usually self-limiting, and treatment is supportive.
Option 1 Kimura disease: A rare chronic inflammatory disorder that primarily affects the lymph nodes and soft tissues. It is characterized by painless subcutaneous nodules, lymphadenopathy (especially in the head and neck region), and increased eosinophil levels in the blood.

Option 3 Hodgkin's disease (Hodgkin lymphoma): A type of lymphoma characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells in the lymph nodes. It typically presents as painless, rubbery lymph node enlargement, commonly in the neck, armpits, or groin. Other symptoms may include fever, night sweats, weight loss, and generalized itching.

Option 4 Castleman disease (also known as angio follicular lymph node hyperplasia): A rare lymphoproliferative disorder that affects the lymph nodes. It can manifest as unicentric or multicentric disease. Unicentric Castleman disease involves a single lymph node region, while multicentric Castleman disease involves multiple lymph node regions and can be associated with systemic symptoms like fever, fatigue, and weight loss.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 1364.

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered a Neuronal tumor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Ependymoma 
 
  • Ependymoma is a type of primary central nervous system tumor that arises from ependymal cells lining the ventricles of the brain or the central canal of the spinal cord.
  • Ependymoma is derived from glial cells and is classified as a glioma rather than a neuronal tumor.
  • Neuronal tumors arise from neuronal cells and include various types, such as gangliocytoma, ganglioglioma, and neurocytoma.
  • Ependymoma is characterized by a range of clinical presentations depending on the location and size of the tumor and can cause symptoms related to increased intracranial pressure or local mass effect.

NEURONAL TUMORS



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1296.

questions.text: Which is an exception to seeing Psammoma bodies?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid 
 
  • Psammoma bodies are concentrically laminated calcific structures that can be seen within the stroma of certain tumors.
  • They are most commonly associated with papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, serous papillary cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary, and meningioma.
  • Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid is an exception to seeing Psammoma bodies.
  • Follicular carcinoma is characterized by the presence of follicular structures and invasion into blood vessels or thyroid capsule but typically does not exhibit the formation of Psammoma bodies.

Fig: Psammoma Bodies 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 950.

questions.text: In diagnostic pathology which of the following is the most commonly used 'fixative'?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1): Formaldehyde
 
  • Formaldehyde, in the form of formalin, is a widely used fixative for preserving tissue samples for histological examination.
  • It works by cross-linking proteins and nucleic acids, thereby stabilizing cellular structures and preventing tissue degradation.
  • Formaldehyde fixation allows for the preservation of tissue architecture and cellular morphology, enabling accurate microscopic evaluation.
  • It is compatible with various staining techniques and is the standard fixative for routine histopathology.
Online Reference: Rachel C Hart, Darian T Carroll, Maria Vinogradova, Evan S Krystofiak, A Guide to Fixation and Staining of Biological Samples for Electron Microscopy, Microscopy Today, Volume 32, Issue 2, March 2024, Pages 37–40, https://doi.org/10.1093/mictod/qaae009

questions.text: The most common mutation in Ewing's sarcoma is reflected by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Translocation 11:22
 
  • Ewing's sarcoma is a malignant bone and soft tissue tumor primarily affecting children and young adults.
  • It is characterized by a specific chromosomal translocation, t(11;22), involving the EWSR1 gene on chromosome 22 and the FLI1 gene on chromosome 11.
  • This translocation leads to the fusion of EWSR1 and FLI1 genes, resulting in the production of an abnormal fusion protein with oncogenic properties.
  • The translocation t(11;22) is present in approximately 85-90% of Ewing's sarcoma cases.
  • The fusion protein plays a crucial role in the development and progression of Ewing's sarcoma.
     

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1192.

questions.text: Which is the most common agent responsible for UTI in children ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: E.coli

E.coli is the most common cause of UTI in children. It is a gram-negative, coliform bacteria responsible for 80% of cases.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 678.

questions.text: Which oxidase positive Gram negative bacilli shows non lactose fermenting colonies on Mac-Conkey media?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Pseudomonas 

Psuedomonas is oxidase positive, gram negative bacilli. It does not show coloured colonies on Macconkey agar.
Other options – The other three are oxidase negative.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 320.

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to result from Streptococcus Pyogenes?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Scalded Skin syndrome 

Scalded skin syndrome is caused by an exfoliative toxin produced exclusively by Staphylococcus aureus. It is not produced by streptococcus.
Other options- TSS is caused by both Staphylococcus and Streptococcus. The other two skin infections are mostly seen in strep infections.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 215.

questions.text: Which is the most common virus that is implicated in Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) is
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Corona Virus 

The most common cause of SARS worldwide is Coronavirus ie, CoV-2. It belongs to the class betacoronavirus.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 447.

questions.text: Where do we see colonies with Bisected Pearl appearance ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Bordetella 

Bordetella shows colonies that are small, glistening, greyish white. They resemble bisected pearls or mercury drops which is characteristic on Regan-Lowe agar and Bordet-Gengou agar.
on gram staining they show small, ovoid coccobacilli arranged in Thumb print appearance.



Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 339.

questions.text: Exception to statements about Pontiac fever is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option: 2. Pneumonia is most common manifestation
 
  • Legionella pneumophila causes Pontiac fever and Legionnaire's disease.
  • Legionnaire's disease presents with an Influenza-like illness whose symptoms are fever, non-productive cough, and dyspnea and may rarely progress to pneumonia if left untreated, but it is not the most common manifestation.
  • Compared with Legionella pneumonia, Pontiac fever is a milder, self-limited illness that is defined by the absence of pneumonia.
 
  • Diarrhea and encephalopathy are also common.
  • It is often included in the differential diagnosis of atypical pneumonia. Pontiac fever presents with a mild influenza-like illness. 
  • Infection is typically by inhalation of aerosols produced by cooling towers, air conditioners, and showerheads which act as disseminators. 
  • No animal reservoirs exist, no human-to-human transmission occurs, and no carrier state is established. It is an epidemic.
  • Pontiac fever is self-limiting, and antibiotic therapy is not typically needed. Treatment is mainly Supportive.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1253, 1255.

questions.text: What causes Weil's disease ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Leptospira interrogans

Leptospira interrogans is indicated in Weil’s disease. It is characterized by ictohemorrhagic fever and hepatorenal syndrome.
Other options- Borrelia recurrentis- Relapsing fever
Treponema endemicum- Syphilis
Borrelia burdoferi- Lyme’s disease

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 388.

questions.text: Which of the following Rickettsial Diseases is associated with fever, tunica reaction and scrotal necrosis on guinea pig inoculation?
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1. Rickettsia rickettsii.
  • Rickettsia rickettsii is the causative agent of Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF), which is a tick-borne disease that affects humans.
  • The disease is characterized by fever, headache, muscle pain, and a rash. Inoculation of guinea pigs with Rickettsia rickettsii causes fever, tunica reaction (inflammation of the tunica vaginalis, a membrane that covers the testes), and scrotal necrosis (death of tissue in the scrotum). This is a diagnostic test for the disease, as it helps to confirm the presence of Rickettsia rickettsii in the sample. Rickettsia prowazekii is the causative agent of epidemic typhus, which is transmitted by body lice.
  • Rickettsia akari is the causative agent of rickettsialpox, which is transmitted by mites. Rickettsia typhi is the causative agent of murine typhus, which is transmitted by fleas.
  • These diseases have different clinical presentations and diagnostic tests compared to RMSF.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 415.

questions.text: Where do we see Owl's Eye Inclusion bodies ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: CMV 

Owl’s eye inclusion bodies are the hallmark of CMV infection. It is an intranuclear inclusion surrounded by a clear halo.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 480.

questions.text: The causative agent for Delhi Boil is
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: L . Tropica 

Delhi boil is caused by L.Tropica. It is a type of cutaneous leishmaniasis characterised by ulcerative lesions of the skin. It was once very common in India, particularly Delhi and hence the name.
Other options: L. Donovani - VL
L. Braziliens - CL
L.Mexicana- CL

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 61.

questions.text: Which is the most common Helminthic disease associated with myocarditis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Trichinella 

Trichenella spiralis is most commonly associated with myocarditis.
Trichinella spiralis-associated myocarditis does not result due to the direct larval invasion of the myocardium with encystation but is caused most likely by an eosinophil-enriched inflammatory response which leads to eosinophilic myocarditis.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 173.

questions.text: Which of the following protozoa is not detected by Fecal Acid Fast Stain?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Microsporidia 

This technique is useful for the identification of oocysts of the coccidian species (Cryptosporidium, Cystoisospora, and Cyclospora), which may be difficult to detect with routine stains such as trichrome.
Microsporidia is an obligate intracellular fungus which is treated as protozoa. It is an unicellular parasite which can be detected with routine stain.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 105.

questions.text: What is Rabies vaccine encephalitis an example of?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Molecular mimicry 

Molecular mimicry plays an important role in immune responses to infection and in autoimmune diseases. Infection may induce autoimmune responses which attack and destroy body tissues or organs. Normally, the body is tolerant to self-antigens which are present in individual tissues. Rabies vaccine encephalitis is a prime example of this.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 539.

questions.text: Which of the following immunoglobulins is a pentamer?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4:  Ig M 

IgM is a pentamer. It forms groups of five in solution.
Other options- IgA - Dimer
IgD - Monomer
IgG - Monomer

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 106.

questions.text: What is Phenol Coefficient test for testing the efficacy of disinfectants in the presence of organic matter
Which of the following is an exception to actions of muscarinic antagonists ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Contract radial muscles of iris 
 
  • Muscarinic antagonists, also known as anticholinergic drugs, block the action of acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors.
  • The general effects of muscarinic antagonists include:
    • Decrease in secretions
    • Relaxation of smooth muscles
    • Dilation of the pupils.
  • Muscarinic antagonists typically decrease gastric secretions (option 1) and decrease respiratory secretions (option 2).
  • However, muscarinic antagonists do not contract the radial muscles of the iris (option 3). Instead, they block the action of acetylcholine on circular muscle, causing passive mydriasis and called cycloplegics.
  • Muscarinic antagonists can also have an effect on AV conduction, as they can block the parasympathetic influence on the AV node, which may result in AV nodal block or decreased AV conduction (option 4).
* [Extra Edge]: Muscarinic Agonist Vs Antagonist



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 112.

questions.text:
How is Buprenorphine classified?
1. Partial agonist at \(\mu\) receptor 
2. Partial agonist at \(\kappa\) receptors
3. Full agonist at \(\mu\) receptor 
4. Full agonist at \(\kappa\) receptors
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Partial agonist at μ receptors

Buprenorphine is a partial μ agonist and an antagonist at δ and κ receptors. It is used as an analgesic and in the management of opioid dependence. It does not have an effect on the neuronal uptake of serotonin so is not implicated in causing serotonin syndrome. 

* [Extra Edge]: Opioids
All opioid agonist-antagonists are µ antagonists and k agonists, except buprenorphine and dezocine. Buprenorphine and dezocine are partial agonists at the μ receptor.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 508.

questions.text: Which is an exception to an opioid tolerance development action?

choices.text: Acts on the dorsal horn substantia gelatinosa

questions.text: Which is not true about Epidural opioids ?
Which of the following drug is most commonly used worldwide in maintenance doses for opioid dependence?
What is not true about serotonin syndrome ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Dantrolene is the drug of choice

Serotonin syndrome occurs due to the combined side effects with any drug that increases serum serotonin levels like MAOIs (monoamine oxidase inhibitors), SSRIs (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors), SNRIs (serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors), TCAs (tricyclic antidepressants), tramadol, ondansetron, triptans, linezolid, MDMA (amphetamine), dextromethorphan, etc.

* Serotonin syndrome – TRIAD:
  • Autonomic instability - hyperthermia, hypertension, tachycardia, diaphoresis, vomiting, diarrhea.
  • Altered mental status - agitation, confusion, delirium.
  • Neuromuscular hyperactivity - tremor, hyperreflexia, myoclonus.
* Cyproheptadine is the drug of choice in serotonin syndrome.

Option 3 Dantrolene reduces spasticity in upper motor neuron disorders, hemiplegia, paraplegia, cerebral palsy and multiple sclerosis. 
Used I.V. it is the drug of choice for malignant hyperthermia which is due to persistent release of Ca2+ from sarcoplasmic reticulum (induced by fluorinated anesthetics and Succinylcholine in genetically susceptible individuals with abnormal RyR1).

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 488.

questions.text: Out of the following agents, which is not associated with Hyperthermia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Alcohol

Alcohol intoxication would cause features like blackouts, nystagmus, slurred speech etc.
Hyperthermia is not a feature seen with it.
Intoxication with all other drugs causes hyperthermia. 


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 417.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis in case of a patient who was given primaquine develops dark coloured urine one day after administration of the drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency
 
  • Primaquine is an antimalarial medication commonly used for the treatment and prevention of malaria.
  • It is known to cause hemolytic anemia in individuals with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.
  • G6PD deficiency is an inherited enzyme deficiency that affects red blood cells, making them more susceptible to oxidative damage.
  • When individuals with G6PD deficiency are exposed to certain triggers, such as certain medications or infections, their red blood cells can undergo hemolysis, resulting in the release of hemoglobin.
  • The breakdown products of hemoglobin can give urine a dark or reddish color, known as hemoglobinuria.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 76.

questions.text: Which deficiency is caused by the Prolonged treatment with INH ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Pyridoxine 
 
  • Isoniazid (INH) is an antitubercular medication commonly used for the treatment of tuberculosis (TB).
  • Prolonged use of INH can lead to a deficiency of pyridoxine (vitamin B6).
  • INH inhibits the conversion of pyridoxine to its active form, pyridoxal phosphate, which is required for various enzymatic reactions in the body.
* Side effects of isoniazid include:
  • Peripheral neuritis due to interference with the production of active coenzyme pyridoxal phosphate from pyridoxine. Therefore, pyridoxine 10mg/day (vitamin B6) is given prophylactically along with isoniazid to prevent neurotoxicity.
  • Hepatitis - isoniazid must be stopped at the first sign of hepatotoxicity.
  • Rashes
  • Anaemia
  • Arthralgia
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 818.

questions.text:
Which of the following electrolytes is mandatorily monitored during Amphotericin B treatment?
1. \(Na^+\)
2. \(Ca^{2+}\)
3. \(K^+\)
4. \(Mg^{2+}\)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) \(K^+\)
 
  • Amphotericin B can cause renal toxicity, leading to renal tubular dysfunction and electrolyte imbalances.
  • One of the most significant electrolyte imbalances associated with Amphotericin B is hypokalemia (low potassium levels).
  • Hypokalemia can occur due to increased renal potassium excretion caused by the medication.
  • Therefore, regular monitoring of potassium (K+) levels is essential during Amphotericin B treatment to ensure appropriate management and prevention of complications.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 839.

questions.text: Which of the following Integrase inhibitors is approved for HIV1 and HIV 2 ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Raltegravir 
 
  • Raltegravir is an integrase inhibitor and is active against both HIV-1 and HIV-2. It can be used in adults and children >1 month old.
  • Integrase inhibitors block the action of the enzyme integrase, which is responsible for integrating the viral DNA into the host cell's DNA during the replication of the HIV virus.
  • By inhibiting integrase, Raltegravir prevents the integration of viral DNA into the host cell's DNA, thereby inhibiting viral replication.
  • Raltegravir is commonly used as part of combination antiretroviral therapy (ART) for the management of HIV infection.
  • Elvitegravir is effective against hiv-1 but it's efficacy against hiv-2 is not proven yet.
  • Lopinavir and Indinavir are protease inhibitors.
* [Extra Edge]: Lifecycle of HIV



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 866.

choices.text: Hypoglycemia is less common than with sulfonylureas

questions.text: Which of the statements is not true about bout meglitinides ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Act by decreasing insulin resistance 
 
  • Meglitinides are oral antidiabetic medications used for type 2 diabetes.
  • Meglitinides work by stimulating insulin release from pancreatic beta cells, which helps to lower blood glucose levels.
  • Meglitinides do not have a direct effect on insulin resistance.
  • They are insulin secretagogues that act by inhibiting the ATP-sensitive K+ channels of the beta cells of the pancreas to cause insulin release.
Anti Diabetic Drugs
Class Examples Mechanism of Action
1. Insulin - Regular insulin- Long-acting (e.g., glargine)- Rapid-acting (e.g., lispro) Mimics natural insulin to control blood glucose.
2. Insulin Secretagogues - DPP-4 Inhibitors: sitagliptin, saxagliptin, linagliptin
 GLP-1 Agonists: exenatide, liraglutide
Sulfonylureas: glibenclamide, glimepiride
 Meglitinides: repaglinide, nateglinide		 Stimulate insulin release from the pancreas.
3. Drugs that Reduce Insulin Resistance - Biguanides: metformin
Thiazolidinediones (TZDs): pioglitazone, rosiglitazone		 Improve insulin sensitivity in muscle and fat.
4. SGLT-2 Inhibitors - Empagliflozin- Canagliflozin Increase glucose excretion by inhibiting renal glucose reabsorption.
5. Alpha-glucosidase Inhibitors - Acarbose- Miglitol Slow carbohydrate breakdown, reducing post-meal blood sugar spikes.
6. Amylin Analogs - Pramlintide Delay gastric emptying and reduce glucagon release.
7. Bile Acid Sequestrants - Colesevelam Improve insulin sensitivity and lower blood glucose.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 296.

choices.text: May be used as first line agent in chronic angina
Works by decreasing the late sodium current in cardiac cells

questions.text: Which of the statements is not true about Ranolazine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) May be used as first line agent in chronic angina

Ranolazine is FDA and EMA approved as a second-line agent for the treatment of chronic angina. The drug may be used with a variety of other agents, including β blockers, Ca2+ channel blockers, ACEIs, ARBs, and therapeutic agents for lowering lipids and reducing platelet aggregation.

Option 1, 3 and 4 are true statements -
  • Ranolazine is an antianginal medication that works by decreasing the late sodium current in cardiac cells, which can lead to a reduction in myocardial ischemia. 
  • Ranolazine is a piperazine derivative and is used as an antianginal medication. It is used when other treatments are not effective or not tolerated.
  • Ranolazine may improve glycemic control in patients with diabetes. It does not directly affect blood glucose levels, but it may improve insulin sensitivity and glucose uptake in peripheral tissues.
  • It is important to note that although hypotension is not an established adverse effect of ranolazine, it may cause other adverse effects such as dizziness, headache, constipation, and nausea. 

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page No 500.

choices.text: Used in the treatment of breast cancer
Slower acting, safer and less effective than SERM
May be administered as 'once a month' dose

questions.text: Which of the statements is not true about Selective Estrogen Receptor Downregulator (SERD), Fulvestrant ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Slower acting, safer and less effective than SERM 
 
  • Fulvestrant is an estrogen antagonist which is indicated in postmenopausal women with hormone-positive breast cancer, which is progressive even after first-line therapy such as tamoxifen.
  • It is longer acting and is administered once a month (250- 500mg) intramuscularly. It is generally well tolerated.
  • It is given as initial biweekly loading doses in the 1st month followed by once-monthly injections. Steady-state levels are achieved in the first month.
  • It is as effective as SERM
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 337.

choices.text: Used in Non small cell lung carcinoma

questions.text: Which of the statements is not true about Erlotinib?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Food decreases its absorption 
 
  • Erlotinib is a reversible EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor used for advanced non-small cell lung cancer(NSCLC) with mutant EGFR and advanced pancreatic cancer in combination with gemcitabine.
  • It works by inhibiting the activity of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) tyrosine kinase, which plays a role in cancer cell growth and survival.
  • One of the common side effects of Erlotinib is the development of skin rashes, which can range from mild to severe.
  • Erlotinib can be taken with or without food, as food does not significantly affect its absorption.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 930.

questions.text: Which of the statements is not true about 'Aprepitant' ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Agonist at Neurokinin receptor (NK1) 
 
  • Aprepitant is a neurokinin receptor antagonist that is used treatment of cytotoxic (chemotherapy) drug-induced vomiting. It is the doc of late onset chemotherapy induced nausea and vomiting.
  • It works by blocking the action of substance P, a neurotransmitter that plays a role in triggering nausea and vomiting.
  • Aprepitant is known to cross the blood-brain barrier, which allows it to exert its effects centrally in the brain.
  • It is metabolized primarily by the CyP3A4 pathway in the liver.
  • The primary therapeutic use of Aprepitant is to ameliorate the nausea and vomiting associated with chemotherapy regimens.
* [Extra Edge]: Mechanism of Action



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 718.

questions.text: The agent used for the treatment of thrombocytopenia secondary to myelosuppressive cancer chemotherapy.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Oprelvekin 
 
  • Oprelvekin is an IL-11 analog used in the treatment of chemotherapy-induced thrombocytopenia. It increases thrombopoiesis.
  • It is used in the treatment of thrombocytopenia due to non-myeloid malignancies.
  • Important adverse effects are fluid retention, tachycardia, palpitation, edema, and shortness of breath.
* Other options:
  • Filgrastim (A) and Sargramostim (B) are agents that stimulate the production of white blood cells, particularly neutrophils, and are used to treat neutropenia in cancer patients.
  • Erythropoietin (D) is a hormone that stimulates the production of red blood cells and is used to treat anemia but is not effective for thrombocytopenia.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 906.

questions.text: Which of the following antihypertensive drugs should not be used in a patient on Lithium in order to prevent Lithium Toxicity
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Diuretics
 
  • Thiazide diuretics are known to decrease the renal clearance of Lithium, which can lead to an increase in Lithium levels in the blood.
  • This effect is due to the fact that Thiazides reduce the excretion of Sodium in the kidneys, leading to increased Sodium reabsorption at PCT and this leads to decreased Lithium secretion. This can result in Lithium toxicity.
* [Extra Edge]: Lithium 


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 477.

questions.text: Which is an exception to adverse effects of thalidomide?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Diarrhea  
 
  • Thalidomide is a medication known for its history of causing severe birth defects in children, including phocomelia ( abnormally short or absent limbs) when taken by pregnant women.
  • Thalidomide can have several adverse effects, including neuropathy, somnolence, dizziness, constipation, and deep vein thrombosis (DVT).
  • However, diarrhea is not commonly associated with thalidomide use, unlike the other mentioned side effects.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 936.

questions.text: Which of the following chemotherapeutic drugs is used for the Alkalinization of urine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Methotrexate
 
  • The chemotherapeutic drug that is used for the alkalinization of urine is Methotrexate.
  • Methotrexate is a chemotherapy drug that is used to treat cancer, autoimmune diseases, and ectopic pregnancies.
  • It works by inhibiting the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase, which is responsible for the synthesis of folic acid. This inhibition leads to a decrease in the production of DNA and RNA, which results in the death of rapidly dividing cells, including cancer cells.
  • In addition to its use in cancer treatment, Methotrexate is also used to alkalinize urine.
  • This is because Methotrexate is a weak organic acid that is excreted in the urine. When the urine is acidic, Methotrexate can precipitate out of solution and form crystals, which can cause kidney damage.
  • However, when the urine is alkalinized, Methotrexate remains in solution and is more easily excreted from the body, reducing the risk of kidney damage.
Therefore, Methotrexate is the correct option for the chemotherapeutic drug used for the alkalinization of urine.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 921.

questions.text: An exception to presence of Mineralocorticoid Receptors is -
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Liver 
 
  • Mineralocorticoid receptors (MR) are a type of nuclear receptor that specifically binds to mineralocorticoid hormones, such as aldosterone.
  • These receptors are primarily found in target tissues that are involved in electrolyte and fluid balance regulation, such as the kidney, colon, and certain parts of the brain.
  • However, the exception to the presence of mineralocorticoid receptors is the liver (option A).
  • Unlike other target tissues, the liver does not express significant levels of mineralocorticoid receptors.
  • Instead, the liver primarily expresses glucocorticoid receptors (GR), which mediate the effects of glucocorticoid hormones like cortisol.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 1010.

questions.text: Specify the classification of Temozolomide?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Alkylating Agent
 
  • Temozolomide is an oral chemotherapy drug used in the treatment of certain types of brain tumors, such as glioblastoma multiforme and anaplastic astrocytoma.
  • Mechanism of action -  deposit Methyl groups on DNA guanine bases - hence - it works similar to alkylating agents.
Therefore, Temozolomide is classified as an Alkylating Agent

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 920.

questions.text: A drug 'A' is already in use and drug B needs to be introduced. The value of the new drug in relation to the old drug can be established by which phase of drug trial?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Phase III 
 
  • Phase III trials are large-scale, randomized, controlled trials that compare the efficacy and safety of the new drug (drug B) with the standard treatment (drug A) or a placebo.
  • These trials involve a larger number of participants and are designed to provide more definitive evidence of the effectiveness and safety of the new drug.




Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 91.

questions.text: The preferred method of drug designing is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Target-structure based
 
  • Structure-based drug design (SBDD) and ligand-based drug design (LBDD) are the two general types of computer-aided drug design (CADD) approaches in existence.
  • SBDD methods analyze macromolecular target 3-dimensional structural information, typically of proteins or RNA, to identify key sites and interactions that are important for their respective biological functions.
  • Such information can then be utilized to design antibiotic drugs that can compete with essential interactions involving the target and thus interrupt the biological pathways essential for the survival of the microorganism(s). 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 88.

questions.text: Greenish discoloration of the right iliac fossa area during putrefaction is caused by:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Sulphmethemoglobin

Greenish discoloration results from the conversion of haemoglobin of blood into sulphmethaemoglobin by the hydrogen sulphide formed in the large intestine and escaping into the surrounding tissues

The first external sign of putrefaction in a body lying in air is usually a greenish discoloration of the skin over the region of the caecum.

The order of putrefaction from 1st organ to last is 
  • Larynx and Trachea
  • Stomach and intestine
  • Lungs and liver
  • Brain
  • Heart
  • Kidney
  • Prostate and Uterus
  • Muscles, tendons
  • Skin
  • Bones 
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33RD Edition, Page No 165.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in Heat rupture
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Irregular margin.

Heat ruptures or splits in the skin may be several centimeters in length, and superficially they may resemble lacerations or even incised wounds. They can be differentiated by: 
  • Absence of bleeding in the wound and surrounding tissues, since heat coagulates the blood in vessels.
  • Intact vessels and nerves are seen in the floor.
  • Irregular margins. 
  • Absence of bruising or other signs of vital reaction in the margins.
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 323.

questions.text: Hide and die Reaction with terminal Burrowing is seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Hypothermia

A pattern of behavior seen in death from hypothermia in which the victim hides in a cupboard or other confined space either to seek warmth or because of the confusion caused by hypothermia

Hypothermia is defined as a core body temperature of <35 degree Celsius



Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 318.

questions.text: Fencing posture is caused by:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Coagulation of proteins.

The posture of a body which has been exposed to great heat is often characteristically called fencing posture, pugilistic, defense attitude or boxing attitude. 
 
  • Contraction of paraspinal muscles often causes a marked opisthotonus, in an attitude commonly adopted by boxers. 
  • This stiffening is due to the coagulation of proteins of the muscles and dehydration which cause contraction. The flexor muscles being bulkier than extensors contract more due to which joints of all limbs are flexed.
  • It occurs whether the person was alive or dead at the time of burning




Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 322.

questions.text: Streaming of nuclei' on histopathology is seen in death due to
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Electrocution

Electrocution is death caused by passage of electric current.

Histopathology: Larger vacuoles are produced within the epidermal cells, the nuclei of which are fusiform, hyperchromatic and show a peculiar distortion with stretching and narrowing of the contour and produce palisade-type appearance. This change is called streaming of the nuclei.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 332.

questions.text: Ladder tears are :
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Transverse tears of aortic intima

An aortic rupture is circular and clean-cut, and appears as sharp as if it has been transected with a knife.

Sometimes multiple transverse intimal tears are seen adjacent to the main rupture called as "ladder tears."

The mechanism involves the sudden deceleration that occurs during a crash, which can cause the aorta to stretch and tear, especially at points where it is anchored or where there are natural anatomical variations.



Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 282.

questions.text: Active male agent in sodomy when passive agent is a child(boy) is known as
questions.solution:
Correct option 2:Pederast

Sodomy between adult and child is known pedarast. 
The adult(active partner) is known as pedarast while the child(passive agent) is known as catamite.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 427.

questions.text: Corpus Delicti deals with
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Body of offence

Corpus delicti is a Latin term meaning "body of the crime/offence." It is the essential facts that prove that a crime has been committed. For example, a person cannot be convicted of Shoplifting unless the prosecutor can demonstrate the property was stolen.  Here, the stealing of the item becomes “corpus delicti.”

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 57.

questions.text: Which section of IPC defines hurt as bodily pain, disease or infirmity?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: 319.

319, I.P.C.: HURT: Hurt means bodily pain,
disease or infirmity caused to any person. It does not include mental pain

Option 2: S.323. I.P.C.: Punishment for voluntarily causing hurt: Imprisonment up to one year, or with fine up to one thousand rupees or both

Option 3: S.320, I.P.C.: GRIEVOUS HURT: Any of the following injuries are grievous. 
  • Emasculation. 
  • Permanent privation of sight of either eye. 
  • Permanent privation of hearing of either ear. 
  • Privation of any member or joint.
  • Destruction or permanent impairing of the power of any member or joint.
  • Permanent disfiguration of the head or face.
  • Fracture or dislocation of a bone or tooth.
  • Any hurt which endangers life, or which causes the victim to be in severe bodily pain, or unable to follow his ordinary pursuits for a period of twenty days.
Option 4: S.322. I.P.C.: Voluntarily causing grievous hurt

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 292.

questions.text: Identify the withdrawal symptoms described by Cold Turkey:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Opioid withdrawal.

Opioid withdrawal consists of severe muscle cramps and bone aches, profuse diarrhea, abdominal cramps, rhinorrhea, lacrimation, piloerection or gooseflesh (from which comes the term cold turkey for the abstinence syndrome)

Opioid withdrawal symptoms:



Option 2: Cocaine withdrawal: 
  • dysphoric mood
  • fatigue
  • vivid, unpleasant dreams
  • insomnia or hypersomnia
  • increased appetite
  • psychomotor retardation or agitation 

Option 3: Alcohol withdrawal 



Other symptoms 
hypertension, tachycardia and sweating, anxiety, depressed mood and irritability, transient hallucinations and illusions, headache and insomnia. 

Option 4: benzodiazepine withdrawal
  • fits and psychosis
  • anxiety symptoms such as sweating, insomnia, headache, tremors, nausea
  • disordered perception such as feelings of unreality, abnormal bodily sensations 
  • hypersensitivity to stimuli

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 585.

questions.text: What is the cause of Jamaican Vomiting Sickness?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Hypoglycin.

Ingestion of unripe Ackee fruit results in a metabolic syndrome known as Jamaican vomiting sickness.
The toxic responsible is Hypoglycin A
Symptoms of vomiting manifest within 6-48 hours of ingestion 
Recovery takes 1 week.




Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 554.

questions.text: All of the following indicators represent Human Development Index, Except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Life Expectancy at 1 year of age 

The components of the Human Development Index (HDI) include life expectancy at birth, literacy, and standard of living.
Human Development Index (HDI) is a measure of a country's average achievements in three dimensions of human development:
 
  • A long and healthy life, as measured by life expectancy at birth
  • Knowledge (literacy), as measured by mean years of schooling and expected years of schooling, and
  • A decent standard of living, as measured by GNI (gross national income) per capita

HDI values range from 0 to 1, with 1 as the maximum value.





Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 17.

questions.text: A good index of the severity of an acute disease is expressed by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2:  Case fatality rate 

A good index of the severity of an acute disease is expressed by Case fatality rate.
  • The formula for calculating the Case Fatality Rate (CFR) is:
        CFR = (Number of deaths from the disease / Number of confirmed cases of the disease) x 100
  • Case fatality rate represents the killing power of a disease.
  • It is simply the ratio of deaths to cases. The time interval is not specified.
  • Case fatality rate is typically used in acute infectious diseases (e.g., food poisoning, cholera, measles).
  • Its usefulness for chronic diseases is limited, because the period from onset to death is long and variable.
  • The case fatality rate for the same disease may vary in different epidemics because of changes in the agent, host and environmental factors. Case fatality is closely related to virulence.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 66.

questions.text: The dominator in estimating Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is represented by -
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Total number of live births .
 
  • Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is a crucial indicator of maternal health, measuring the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births in a given time period.
  • To calculate MMR, the total number of live births is used as the dominator.
  • This denominator reflects the population at risk of maternal deaths, as it includes all women who gave birth during the specified period.
  • In India, the most common causes of maternal deaths are hemorrhage (leading cause), sepsis, obstructed labor, hypertensive disorders, etc.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 635.

questions.text: Exception to Chronic carrier state is -
questions.solution:
Measles does not have a chronic carrier state.
  • Once a person recovers from measles, they do not carry or spread the virus.
  • Diseases like typhoid, gonorrhea and diphtheria, however, can have chronic carriers who can continue to spread the disease even after they recover.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 166.

questions.text: Prophylaxis of which of the following disease uses tetracycline as a treatment-
questions.solution:
• Tetracycline is used in the prophylaxis and treatment of cholera to reduce the severity and duration of symptoms and to prevent the disease in at-risk populations.
 
  • While tetracycline can be used in the treatment of brucellosis and leptospirosis, it is particularly noted for its use in cholera prophylaxis.
THE FOLLOWING TABLE ESTIMATES THE DISEASES FOR WHICH CHEMOPROPHYLAXIS IS USED AND THE DRUGS USED FOR THE RESPECTIVE DISEASES :-




Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 139.

questions.text: Exception to transmission of infection by Vectors is-
questions.solution:
Ingestion is not a typical mode of transmission for vector-borne diseases.

Vector-borne transmission typically occurs through mechanisms such as
  • regurgitation (where the vector, like a mosquito, regurgitates infectious agents into the host while feeding),
  • rubbing of infected feces (as seen with some insect-borne diseases like Chagas disease), or 
  • contamination with body fluids.


Ingestion refers to the consumption of contaminated food or water and is not how vectors typically transmit infections.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 106.

questions.text: Which of the following represents a non deliberate cultural practice leading to anti-mosquito effect:
questions.solution:
Use of alkaline detergent is considered a non-deliberate cultural practice that can have an anti-mosquito effect because 
 
  • it can kill mosquito larvae or
  • reduce mosquito breeding sites by altering the pH of water sources.   


The other options (larvicidal agents, bed nets, and repellents) are deliberate and intentional methods used to control mosquito populations or prevent bites.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 314.

questions.text: All of the following factors are responsible for resurgence of malaria, Except:
questions.solution:
Use of bed nets actually helps in reducing malaria transmission by protecting people from mosquito bites, especially at night.

The resurgence of malaria is mainly due to
  • drug resistance in the parasite,
  • insecticide resistance in vectors, and
  • antigenic mutations in the parasite that help it evade the immune response.


Thus, bed nets are a preventive measure, not a factor in the resurgence.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 311.

questions.text: Which insect amongst the following has not developed resistance to DDT
questions.solution:
Kala-azar, also known as visceral leishmaniasis, is a serious parasitic disease caused by the Leishmania species, primarily Leishmania donovani. The disease is transmitted through the bites of infected sandflies, specifically the Phlebotomus species in the Old World and Lutzomyia in the New World.
Control measures often include the use of insecticides, and DDT (dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane) has been historically used in mosquito control programs.




Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 355.

questions.text: Which of the following Arboviral diseases is not found in India
questions.solution:
Yellow Fever is not found in India.
 
  • The other diseases—West Nile Fever, Dengue, and Sandfly Fever—are present in India.
  • Yellow fever is endemic in parts of Africa and South America, but not in India.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 327.

choices.text: Two to three cases per village may suggest an Epidemic
All individuals bitten by infected mosquitoes develop disease
Children are more  frequently affected than adults

questions.text: All of the following statements about Japenese Encephalitis are true, Except:
questions.solution:
• Not all individuals bitten by infected mosquitoes develop Japanese Encephalitis.
  • In fact, the vast majority of infections are asymptomatic or result in mild symptoms.
  • The statement that all bitten individuals develop the disease is incorrect.
 
  • The other statements are accurate:
  1. a small number of cases in a village can suggest an epidemic,
  2. children are more frequently affected, and
  3. the ratio of inapparent to apparent infections is quite high.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 331.

choices.text: Hepatorenal syndrome may occur in upto 50% of patients

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about leptospirosis ?
questions.solution:
Rats are indeed the prime reservoirs of Leptospira,the bacteria that cause leptospirosis.

The other statements are incorrect:
  • fluoroquinolones are not the first-line treatment(doxycycline or penicillin is more commonly used). Doxycycline is the DOC. 
  • person-to-person transmission is very rare, and
  • hepatorenal syndrome does not occur in up to 50% of patients—though it can occur in severe cases, it's not that common.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 338.

questions.text: Which of the following antibiotics is recommended in a case where a sewage worker presents to the Emergency department with fever and jaundice. Laboratory findings reveal an elevated BUN and serum creatinine suggestive of renal failure. Which of the following antibiotics is recommended?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Penicillin G.
 
  • In this scenario, a sewage worker presenting with fever and jaundice and laboratory findings suggestive of renal failure raises suspicion of leptospirosis, a bacterial infection caused by the Leptospira interrogans
  • Leptospirosis is commonly transmitted through contact with water or soil contaminated with the urine of infected animals, and sewage workers are at increased risk.
  • The treatment of choice is IV penicillin or IV ceftriaxone. Doxycycline 200 mg orally given once a week is effective in prophylaxis.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 339.

choices.text: Late stages of yaws involve heart and nerves

questions.text: What is not true about 'yaws'?
questions.solution:
Option 4, "Late stages of yaws involve heart and nerves," is not true.
  • The late stages of yaws involve bone and joint destruction, but do not typically involve the heart or nerves.
  • However, it should be noted that if yaws is left untreated, it can progress to a more severe form of the disease called tertiary yaws, which can affect multiple organs including the heart and nervous system.
  • Yaws is a chronic bacterial infection caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum pertenue.
  • The disease is transmitted through direct contact with the skin of an infected person, typically during childhood.
  • The infection causes lesions on the skin, bones, and cartilage, which can lead to disfigurement and disability if left untreated.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 390.

questions.text: As per Mc Keown's theory, rate of mortality deduction from Tuberculosis was result of -
questions.solution:
In a 1962 article, Mc Keown concluded that “the rise of population was due primarily to the decline of mortality and the most important reason for the decline was an improvement in economic and social conditions.”
Among these conditions, the most significant was improved diet.

Online reference: https://ajph.aphapublications.org/doi/full/10.2105/AJPH.92.5.730

questions.text: The efficiency of pasteurization is assessed by which of the following tests ?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Phosphatase test.

Phosphatase test is used to test the effectiveness of pasteurization of milk.
  • Phosphatase test: It is based on the fact that raw milk contains phosphatase enzyme which gets destroyed at temperatures corresponding to the standard time and temperature required for pasteurization. 



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 770.

questions.text: What does the Ortho toluidine test detect?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Chlorines.
 
  • Ortho toluidine test is used to measure the free and combined chlorines present in the water. 
  • A reading within the first 10 seconds signifies free chlorine, while a reading taken after 15 minutes signifies the total amount of chlorines in the water (free and combined). 
  • Ortho toluidine -arsenite test is able to measure the free and combined chlorines separately in the water.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 842.

questions.text: Which is the least likely causes of indoor air pollution ?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Mercury vapour.
 
  • Mercury vapor is not typically a common cause of indoor air pollution.
  • Indoor air pollution is primarily caused by various factors such as cooking, heating, smoking, use of certain household products, and building materials that release harmful pollutants like carbon monoxide, nitrogen dioxide, volatile organic compounds (VOCs), and particulate matter.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 860.

questions.text: The National Screening/Control Programme is not seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Dental caries 

The NPCDCS (National Program for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Diseases and Stroke) has been changed to NP-NCP (National Program for Prevention and Control of Non-Communicable Diseases).

It now includes initiatives and guidelines on the prevention and management of new diseases like:
  • Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease
  • Chronic Kidney disease
  • Asthma and COPD and
  • STEMI
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 416.

questions.text: Which is an exception to 'Reforms' proposed by the world Health Report (2008)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Economic Reforms 
 
  • The World Health Report 2008 proposed three sets of reforms:
  1. Service reforms to improve the quality and efficiency of health services.
  2. Leadership reforms to strengthen the capacity of health systems to manage change.
  3. Policy reforms to create an enabling environment for health.
  • Economic reforms were not specifically mentioned in the report. However, the report did state that health systems need to be financially sustainable, and that economic reforms can sometimes have a negative impact on health.
Online reference: https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/69863/WHO_IER_WHR_08.1_eng.pdf?sequence=1

questions.text: Direct standardization is done with an objective to compare the mortality rates between two countries. This is done due to the differentiating factor of -
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Age distributions 

It is necessary to do direct standardisation while comparing two countries due to the differentiating factor of age distribution. If standardisation is not done, the mortality rate will be higher in a country with more elderly population.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 66.

questions.text: Choose the Term of sampling, where a village is divided into five relevant subgroups for the purpose of a survey. Individuals from each subgroup are then selected randomly.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2:  Stratified sampling 
  • Stratified random sampling involves dividing the population into subgroups or strata based on specific characteristics that are relevant to the study.
  • Within each stratum, a random sample is drawn, and the size of the sample from each stratum is proportional to the size of that stratum in the overall population.
  • Researchers often use stratified random sampling when the population is Heterogeneous.                

Types of sampling


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 913.

questions.text: Choose the term of sampling where region is divided into 50 villages for the purposes of a survey. 10 villages are then selected randomly for the purpose of a study.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Cluster Sampling
 
  • Cluster sampling involves dividing the population into smaller, more manageable groups or clusters. Once the clusters are defined, a random sample of clusters is selected. Then a random subset of individuals within the selected clusters is included in the final sample.
  •  Simple random sample : This is done by assigning a number to each of the units (the individuals or households) in the sampling frame. A table of random numbers is then used (see page 853) to determine which units are to be included in the sample. Random numbers are a haphazard collection of certain numbers, arranged in a cunning manner to eliminate personal selection of unconscious bias in taking out the sample. With this procedure, the sample is drawn in such a way that each unit has an equal chance of being drawn in the sample. This technique provides the greatest number of possible samples.
  • Systematic random sample : This is done by picking every 5th or 10th unit at regular intervals. For example, to carry out a filaria survey in a town, we take 10 per cent sample. The houses are numbered first. Then a number is selected at random between 1 and 10 (say four). Then every 10th number is selected from that point on 4, 14, 24, 34, etc. By this method, each unit in the sampling frame would have the same chance of being selected, but the number of possible samples is greatly reduced.
  • Stratified random sample : The sample is deliberately drawn in a systematic way so that each portion of the sample represents a corresponding strata of the universe. This method is particularly useful where one is interested in analysing the data by a certain characteristic of the population, viz. Hindus, Christians, Muslims, age-groups etc. - as we know these groups are not equally distributed in the population.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 913.

questions.text: What is the gold standard test for the diagnosis of Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH) is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Flow cytometry 
 
  • Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria is a rare, acquired disorder characterized by the deficiency of glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI)-anchored proteins on the cell surface.
  • Flow cytometry is used to detect and quantify the absence or reduced expression of GPI-anchored proteins, such as CD55 and CD59, on red blood cells, granulocytes, and monocytes.
  • This test is essential for confirming the diagnosis of PNH and assessing the extent of GPI-anchored protein deficiency.
  • Other tests, such as sucrose hemolysis and Ham test, can also provide supportive evidence for PNH diagnosis.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 649.

choices.text: Acute hemolysis can be precipitated by fava beans

questions.text: Which of the following is false with regards to G6PD deficiency?
questions.solution:
• Correct Option is 4: X-linked recessive disorder that does not affect homozygous females 
  • Since G6PD deficiency is X linked recessive, the females are thus carriers
  • Therefore, if the female is heterozygote then they won't be affected ; but if the female is homozygote they will have the disease. 
  • G6PD deficiency is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern, primarily affecting males. Females can be carriers and may have mild symptoms depending on X-inactivation.
  • G6PD is an enzyme that protects red blood cells (RBCs) from oxidative damage. Its deficiency makes RBCs more susceptible to oxidative stress, leading to hemolysis.
  • Hemolytic episodes can be triggered by certain factors, such as infections, certain medications (e.g., sulfa drugs, antimalarials), or consumption of fava beans (favism).
 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 338,654,641

questions.text: What is the shelf life of blood in a blood bank in CPDA buffer:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: 35 days 
 
  • Blood stored in a blood bank is preserved using CPDA buffer to maintain its viability and prevent clotting for transfusions.
  • The blood's shelf life in CPDA buffer extends up to 35 days, allowing it to be safely used for transfusions during this period after its collection.
  • Beyond the 35-day mark, the blood may undergo changes in its cellular and biochemical properties, making it unsuitable for transfusions.

The recommended storage for different blood components are as follows:  





Reference: Wintrobe's Clinical Hematology, 13th edition, Page no 550.
Moore, G L et al. “Some properties of blood stored in anticoagulant CPDA-1 solution. A brief summary.” Transfusion vol. 21,2 (1981): 135-7. doi:10.1046/j.1537-2995.1981.21281178147.x, URL: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/7222197/

questions.text: Where do we see the Epsilon wave?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia 
 
  • The epsilon wave is a characteristic finding seen in the ECG of a patient with arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy.
  • It is a small positive deflection buried at the end of the QRS complex.
  • The sinus rhythm ECG suggests the disease in >85% of patients, most often showing T-wave inversions in V1–V3.
  • Delayed activation of the right ventricle may cause a widened QRS (>110 ms) in the right precordial leads (V1–V3) and a prolonged S-wave upstroke in those leads and, occasionally, a notched deflection at the end of the QRS known as an epsilon wave.

Image showing Epsilon wave seen in ARVD: 





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1921.

questions.text: For patients with Congestive Heart Failure and an ejection fraction of <40 percent i, which is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: ACE-I+ Beta Blocker
 
  • Heart failure is termed HFrEF when the EF is below 40%. The pharmacological management of HfrEF includes two broad categories of drugs:


Combining ACE-I with Beta blocker will have mortality benefit more than other combinations given in options.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1941, 1942.

questions.text: What does -30 to -60 degree axis deviation indicate?
questions.solution:
Correct option 1: Left Axis Deviation (LAD).
  • The normal cardiac axis, which represents the overall direction of electrical activity in the heart, ranges from -30 to +90 degrees.
  • LAD is diagnosed when the QRS complex in lead I is mostly negative and mostly positive in lead aVF.
  • This suggests that the electrical activity in the heart is directed towards the left side of the body, which can be caused by conditions such as left ventricular hypertrophy, conduction abnormalities, or myocardial infarction.
  • It is important to note that LAD can also be a normal variant in some individuals.
 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 516

questions.text: In which of the following is the Duroziez's sign seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Aortic Regurgitation
 
  • Duroziez's sign is heard over the femoral artery.
  • It is elicited by partially compressing the femoral artery with a stethoscope.
  • The sign is associated with a to-and-fro murmur.
  • Duroziez's sign is indicative of aortic regurgitation.

Peripheral signs of Aortic Regurgitation:  




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1988.

questions.text: In which of the following is the Vitum's sign seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Tricuspid Regurgitation 
 
  • Vitum's sign is associated with tricuspid regurgitation and is characterized by a systolic pulsation felt in the right supraclavicular fossa.
  • It is a hepatic Pressure Maneuver to identify Tricuspid Regurgitation on Physical Exam.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2003.

questions.text: Where do we see Carvallo's Sign representing a Diastolic Murmur that increases on inspiration?
questions.solution:
The correct option is option 2-Tricuspid regurgitation
 
  • Carvallo's sign is a physical examination finding that helps to diagnose the cause of a heart murmur.
  • It is characterized by an increase in the intensity of a diastolic murmur during inspiration.
  • The sound may be more audible when the patient is lying on their left side.
  • Increased Ventricular regurgitation ->Increased right ventricular volume ->Increased stroke volume->Velocity of regurgitant flow increases
  • Carvallo's sign disappears in RV failure.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2003.

questions.text: What is the dose of Reteplase for management of Acute MI?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: 10 IU 
 
  • Reteplase is a thrombolytic agent that is used to treat acute myocardial infarction (AMI).
  • It is a tissue plasminogen activator (tPA), which means that it helps to break down blood clots.
  • Reteplase is given as two 10 IU intravenous (IV) injections, 30 minutes apart.

Reteplase:
