questions.text: The target BP must be below which value before thrombolysis can be done in ischemic stroke?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: 185/110 mm Hg 

Contraindications of thrombolysis in stroke:
  • Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Recent head injury or Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Major surgery in the preceding 14 days
  • Minor stroke symptoms
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in preceding 21 days
  • Recent myocardial infarction




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3337, 3338.

questions.text: Identify the one which is not a feature of exudate:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1): Proteins < 3 gm
 
  • Exudate is a type of fluid that accumulates in tissues or body cavities as a result of inflammation or injury.
  • It is characterized by a high protein content (> 3 gm/dL) compared to transudate.
  • Other features of exudate include:
    • Cells > 1000/mm³, predominantly neutrophils.
    • Cloudy appearance due to the presence of inflammatory cells and debris.
    • Elevated levels of inflammatory markers, such as cytokines and acute-phase reactants.
* [Extra Edge]: Exudate Vs Transudate


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 116.

questions.text: Which of the following is the patient's primary disorder in case of a patient was admitted to the casualty with hysteria and anxiety. Estimation of arterial plasma showed PH of 7.53; HCO3 of 18 meq and PCO2 of 27 mm Hg.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Respiratory alkalosis
 
  • pH of 7.53= Alkalosis (higher than normal range of 7.35 to 7.45).
  • HCO3 of 18 = Alkalosis (higher than normal range of 22 to 26 meq).
  • PCO2 of 27= ↓ CO2 levels in blood  (lower than normal range of 35 to 45 mm Hg).
  • These findings collectively indicate respiratory alkalosis, which is caused by a decrease in the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PCO2) due to hyperventilation.
  • The patient's hysteria and anxiety likely triggered hyperventilation, leading to respiratory alkalosis.
  • Hyperventilation leads to excessive CO2 elimination, raising the blood pH.


Trick:- ROMS for pH and pCO2
Respiratory Opposite 
Metabolic Same




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 359, 360.

questions.text: Which diagnosis is suggested by Bilateral upper lobe bronchiectasis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Cystic Fibrosis
 
  • Bilateral upper lobe bronchiectasis strongly suggests cystic fibrosis.
  • Cystic fibrosis is a genetic disorder affecting the respiratory and digestive systems.
  • The condition leads to the production of thick, sticky mucus to build up in the lungs and other organs. This can lead to infections, inflammation, and damage to the lungs.
  • Bronchiectasis is characterized by permanently widened and thickened airways, making mucus clearance difficult.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2174, 2176.
Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 472.

questions.text: What is Brock's Syndrome ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Middle Lobe Bronchiectasis
 
  • Brock's syndrome, also known as Middle Lobe Syndrome, is a condition that affects the middle lobe of the lungs (other lobes are not affected).
  • It is characterized by the presence of bronchiectasis, which is a permanent dilation of the bronchi. This can lead to recurrent infections, inflammation, and damage to the lungs.
  • Symptoms: Chronic cough, sputum production, and recurrent respiratory infections.



Reference: Kunal, Shekhar et al. “Middle lobe syndrome: an intriguing presentation of tracheobronchial amyloidosis.” BMJ case reports vol. 2017 bcr2017219480. 22 May. 2017, doi:10.1136/bcr-2017-219480. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5753675/

questions.text: What is seen with Bronchiectasis Sicca?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Tuberculosis 
 
  • Bronchiectasis Sicca is a term used to describe a specific type of bronchiectasis that presents with dry, non-productive cough without significant sputum production.
  • The term "sicca" comes from Latin, meaning dry. In this condition, the characteristic bronchial dilation and airway damage are present, but the typical symptom of excessive sputum production is not observed.
  • Kartagener syndrome is a specific type of primary ciliary dyskinesia, which can be associated with bronchiectasis but is not the same as bronchiectasis sicca.



Reference: Butler, Marcus W., and Michael P. Keane. “Bronchitis, Bronchiectasis.” Infectious Diseases(2017): 243–250.e2. doi:10.1016/B978-0-7020-6285-8.00027-7. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7150028/

questions.text: Anuria in clinical practice is defined as:
questions.solution:
• Anuria is a medical condition in which the body produces little or no urine.
  • In clinical practice, anuria is defined as a urine output of less than 50 ml per day.
  • Anuria is a serious condition that can lead to the buildup of toxins in the body and can be caused by a variety of factors such as kidney failure, dehydration, and certain medications.
  • Oliguria is defined as <400 mL/24 h.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2279, 2302.

questions.text: Which of the following best defines Microscopic Hematuria as:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: 3 or More RBC/HPF
 
  • Microscopic hematuria : Presence of RBCs in the urine, visible only under a microscope.
  • It is defined as the presence of 3 or more RBCs per high-power field (HPF) on microscopic examination of the urine.
  • Microscopic hematuria is a common finding and can be caused by various conditions like urinary tract infections, kidney stones, and kidney disease.
  • In contrast, gross hematuria refers to visible blood in the urine.

Other options:
 
  • Macroscopic hematuria: Presence of 5 or more RBCs/HPF.
  • Severe hematuria: 25 or more RBCs/HPF and 50 or more RBCs/HPF.



Reference: Bolenz, Christian et al. “The Investigation of Hematuria.” Deutsches Arzteblatt international vol. 115,48 (2018): 801-807. doi:10.3238/arztebl.2018.0801. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6365675/

questions.text: Distal renal tubular acidosis is associated with:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Calcium stones 
 
  • The clinical features of RTA-1 or distal RTA include diarrhea and renal stones with metabolic acidosis, alkaline urine, hypokalemia, positive urine anion gap, and hypercalciuria.
  • RTA-1 occurs due to defective urinary acidification in the cortical collecting tubule due to ineffective H+ ion secretion by the alpha-intercalated cells. This leads to the formation of alkaline urine. The decreased H+ secretion also leads to inadequate HCO3- regeneration in the alpha-intercalated cells thus leading to metabolic acidosis.
 
  • In this condition, calcium phosphate and oxalate stones are formed in the distal convoluting tubules(DCT).
  • Acidemia leads to hypercalcemia and then hypercalciuria. There is also hypocitraturia as acidemia induces increased cell citrate utilization. Normally, citrate in the urine binds to calcium and increases its solubility. In the absence of citrate in the urine, calcium begins to precipitate. This leads to nephrocalcinosis and calcium phosphate and oxalate stones.
     






Reference: Brenner and Rector's The Kidney, 10th edition, Page no 2384.
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th edition, Page no 2172.

questions.text: An exception to low Renin Hypertension is seen in all of the following ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Renovascular hypertension 
 
  • Renal artery stenosis (RAS) is the narrowing of one or both renal arteries, causing high blood pressure, but not low renin levels.
  • Renovascular Hypertension is the exception to the typical pattern of low Renin Hypertension.
  • Renovascular hypertension is high blood pressure caused by narrowed or blocked renal arteries supplying blood to the kidneys.
  • The reduced blood flow triggers the kidneys to produce more renin, resulting in elevated renin levels.
  • In contrast to other conditions associated with low renin levels, Renovascular Hypertension presents with high renin levels due to the narrowed renal arteries.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2088, 2089.

questions.text: Which of the following is an exception to Dent's disease characteristics?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Distal Renal Tubule defect 
 
  • Dent's disease is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by inactivating mutation in CLN5, a chloride transpoter expressed in endosomes of the proximal tubule (Dent disease 1) or OCRL gene mutation (Dent disease 2).
  • Seen more commonly in males.
 
The clinical diagnosis of Dent's disease is based on the presence of all three of the following criteria:
 
  1. LMW proteinuria (elevation of urinary excretion of β2-microglobulin, Clara cell protein and/or RBP by at least 5-fold above the upper limit of normality)
  2. Hypercalciuria (> 4 mg/kg in a 24 h-hour collection or > 0.25 mg Ca2+ per mg creatinine on a spot sample)
  3. At least one of the following: nephrocalcinosis, kidney stones, hematuria, hypophosphataemia, or renal insufficiency


 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2292, 2293.

questions.text: The cause of Dialysis disequilibrium is-
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Reverse Urea effect 
 
  • Dialysis disequilibrium is a condition seen in dialysis patients due to rapid changes in urea and other solute levels in the blood during dialysis.
  • The most common cause of dialysis disequilibrium is the "reverse urea effect",where blood urea levels drop too quickly.
  • Rapid drop in blood urea creates concentration gradient, driving water into brain cells, causing cerebral edema (brain swelling).
  • Symptoms of dialysis disequilibrium include headache, nausea, vomiting, and confusion.
 
  • When DDS is suspected, strong consideration should be given to discontinuing the dialysis treatment.
  • Management of DDS is supportive, as with any other patient with acute neurologic deterioration and suspected raised intracranial pressure and cerebral edema. Maintain the airway and consider hyperventilation.
  • In addition, the cerebral edema can be treated by increasing plasma osmolality with mannitol or hypertonic saline to reduce the osmotic gradient between the blood and brain

Other options:
  • Hypertension, aluminium toxicity, and amyloid deposition are potential complications of dialysis but are not responsible for causing dialysis disequilibrium.


Reference: Mistry, Kirtida. “Dialysis disequilibrium syndrome prevention and management.” International journal of nephrology and renovascular disease vol. 12 69-77. 30 Apr. 2019, doi:10.2147/IJNRD.S165925. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6503314/

questions.text: Which is an exception to Large bowel Colonic Diarrhea associations?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Large Volume stool 

Large Volume stool: In large bowel colonic diarrhea, the stool volume is typically reduced due to impaired water reabsorption in the colon.

Features of Large bowel colonic diarrhea :
  • Urgency: There is a sudden and strong urge to have a bowel movement.
  • Tenesmus: The feeling of incomplete evacuation and persistent desire to pass stool, even after bowel movements.
  • Mucus: Presence of mucus in the stool.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 298, 299.

questions.text: Congenital Hypertrophy of Retinal Pigment Epithelium (CHRPE) is associated with which of the Gastrointestinal Polyposis syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Gardner's syndrome 
 
  • Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) presents with pigmented ocular fundus and is usually associated with familial adenomatous polyposis, and Gardner's syndrome is a subtype of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), a gastrointestinal polyposis syndrome caused by mutations in the APC gene.
  • CHRPE is often found in individuals with Gardner's syndrome, making it a significant clinical feature in the diagnosis of this gastrointestinal polyposis syndrome.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1356.

questions.text: What is Bilateral upper limb pulseless disease is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Takayasu Arteritis
 
  • Takayasu Arteritis is a chronic inflammatory disease that primarily affects large vessels, including the aorta and its major branches.
  • It commonly affects young females and leads to stenosis, occlusion, or aneurysmal dilation of affected vessels.
  • The involvement of the subclavian arteries can cause upper limb pulselessness, known as "pulseless disease."
  • Other features of Takayasu Arteritis include systemic symptoms, such as fever and fatigue, hand claudications, and symptoms related to the affected organs or regions.
VASCULITIS:


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 512.

questions.text: Which is the best provocative test for diagnosis of Gastrinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Secretin injection test 
 
  • Gastrinoma is a rare neuroendocrine tumor that produces excess gastrin, a hormone stimulating stomach acid production.
  • The secretin injection test is used to diagnose gastrinoma by injecting secretin and measuring gastrin levels in the blood afterward.
  • Secretin is a hormone released by the pancreas to regulate stomach acid production in response to food intake.
  • The most sensitive and specific gastrin provocative test for the diagnosis of gastrinoma is the secretin study. An increase in gastrin of ≥120 pg within 15 min of secretin injection has a sensitivity and specificity of >90% for Gastrinoma in ZES. 

Other options:
  • Infusion test: Measures pancreatic function
  • ACTH stimulation test: Assesses adrenal gland function
  • Steroid assay: Measures steroid levels in the blood.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2454.

questions.text: Which is the most common subtype of hepatitis B in India?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Ayw
 
  • Serotyping analysis showed that the most common subtype is ayw (44.33%).
  • Classically, HBV strains were distinguished by the presence of two pairs of mutually exclusive serotype determinants 'd'/'y' and 'w'/'r', in the HBsAg along with the main antigenic determinant 'a', which led to the description of 4 serotypes, namely adw, adr, ayw or ayr.
  • Among these, ayw is the most common subtype, in India.


Reference: Ashrafali Mohamed Ismail, Kalaiselvi Sivalingam Puhazhenthi, Jayashree Sivakumar, Chundamanil Eapen Eapen, Rajesh Kannangai, Priya Abraham, Molecular epidemiology and genetic characterization of hepatitis B virus in the Indian subcontinent, International Journal of Infectious Diseases, Volume 20, 2014, doi: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijid.2013.12.007.
URL: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1201971214000216

questions.text: HBV vaccination is indicated by which of the following serum markers?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Anti-HBs
 
  • Anti-HBs: Indicates successful response to hepatitis B vaccine, providing protection against the virus.
  • HBsAg: Present in blood of individuals with active hepatitis B infection.
  • Anti-HBcIgM: Signals recent hepatitis B infection, present for a few months after infection.
  • Anti-HBc IgG: Indicates past hepatitis B infection, remains in the blood for many years after recovery.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2576.

questions.text: Chronic liver disease can be associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Alpha-1 Antitrypsin deficiency 
 
  • Alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) is a protein that helps to protect the lungs from damage.
  • People with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency do not produce enough AAT, which can lead to damage to the lungs and liver.
  • Chronic liver disease is a condition in which the liver is damaged over a long period of time. It can be caused by a number of factors, including alcohol abuse, hepatitis, and alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.

Other options:
  • Hepatitis A: Viral infection that can cause acute liver inflammation.
  • Chronic malaria: Can cause liver damage, but it is not as common as alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.
  • Infectious mononucleosis: Viral infection that can cause inflammation of the lymph nodes, but it does not typically affect the liver.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2591, 2624.

questions.text: Which is an exception to Zieve syndrome is characteristics?
Which is not true about Wilson's disease?
Where is CDKN1B gene mutation implicated ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: MEN-4
 
  • CDKN1B gene mutation is linked to Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 4 (MEN-4), a rare genetic disorder.
  • MEN-4 results from mutations in the CDKN1B gene, which codes for the p27 protein involved in regulating cell division.
  • These mutations can disrupt p27's normal function, leading to uncontrolled cell growth and tumor development in various endocrine glands.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2984, 2990.

questions.text: What is suggested by early morning hyperglycemia with decreased blood glucose of 2.00 AM ?
questions.solution:
Option is 3: Somogyi effect 
 
  • Early morning hyperglycemia with decreased blood glucose of 2.00 AM suggests the Somogyi effect.
  • The Somogyi effect is also known as "rebound hyperglycemia" in diabetes management.
  • It occurs when the body responds to nighttime hypoglycemia by releasing counterregulatory hormones, leading to elevated blood sugar levels in the morning.

Other options:
  • Insufficient insulin would lead to persistent high blood sugar levels, not the specific pattern seen in the Somogyi effect.
  • The Dawn Phenomenon is a separate phenomenon involving mild morning blood sugar elevation due to natural hormonal release for waking up.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3811.

questions.text: What is the likely cause of no increase in the osmolarity of urine , In a patient who has been given an administration of exogenous vasopressin ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Renal Hyposensitivity to ADH 
 
  • Exogenous vasopressin, also known as ADH (antidiuretic hormone), is naturally produced by the pituitary gland and regulates water retention in the kidneys.
  • When ADH is released,prompts the kidneys to reabsorb more water, leading to increased urine osmolarity.
  • If a patient is given exogenous vasopressin, or synthetic ADH, and  osmolarity of their urine does not increase, it indicates renal hyposensitivity to ADH (Nephrogenic DI). This means that the kidneys are not responding to ADH as they should, and are not reabsorbing as much water as they should.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2921, 2922.

questions.text: Mainstay of treatment of Nephrogenic Diabetes Insipidus is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Thiazide/Amiloride diruetics and salt restriction 

Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI) results due to resistance to the antidiuretic action of AVP (arginine vasopressin) leading to the production of large amounts of dilute urine and dehydration.

NDI mainstay treatment:
  • Thiazide and Amiloride diuretics increase water reabsorption by the kidneys, reducing urine output.
  • Salt restriction helps to further conserve water and prevent excessive loss in the urine.
  • Thiazides are used in nephrogenic diabetes insipidus due to their paradoxical anti-diuretic action. These are the first-line drugs used in the treatment of Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. 
  • The treatment of choice in a Lithium-associated nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is Amiloride.
  • Loop diuretic acts on the N+ K+ 2Cl- symporter, but is not given in diabetes insipidus as it can worsen the condition.

Water deprivation test analysis :





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2922.

questions.text: Which of the following is not related with hypothyroidism?
questions.solution:
Elevated Cholesterol is a feature of Hypothyroidism, NOT Low Cholesterol.
 
  • A normal TSH level excludes primary (but not secondary) hypothyroidism. If the TSH is elevated, a free or unbound T4 level (FT4 ) is needed to confirm the presence of clinical hypothyroidism.
  • T3 is also low in majority of hypothyroid patients.
 
  • Other abnormal laboratory findings in hypothyroidism may include increased creatine phosphokinase, elevated cholesterol and triglycerides, and anemia (usually normocytic or macrocytic).

Evaluation for Hypothyroidism: 





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2935, 2936.

questions.text: Which is a characteristic of Extrapyramidal Tract Involvement?:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1:  Increased Muscular Tone 


Extrapyramidal tract controls smooth voluntary movements.

Involvement of extrapyramidal tract leads to:
  • Increased muscular tone
  • Rigid muscles
  • Shuffling gait
  • Trouble walking
  • Tremor
  • Bradykinesia (slowed movements)
  • Dyskinesia (abnormal movements)
  • Paralysis and positive Babinski sign are not related to extrapyramidal tract involvement.
  • Exaggerated deep tendon reflexes are a characteristic of both extrapyramidal tract involvement and pyramidal tract involvement.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3280.

questions.text: Intracranial hemorrhage is mainly due to which cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Intracerebral hemorrhage
 
  • Intracranial hemorrhage: This type of hemorrhage involves bleeding directly into the brain tissue itself. It is often caused by the rupture of small arteries or veins within the brain.
  • The increased pressure from the bleeding can compress and damage brain tissue, leading to neurological deficits and other complications.
 
  • Causes of intracerebral hemorrhage: High BP, aneurysm, arteriovenous malformation, trauma, drugs, and clotting disorders.

Symptoms can vary depending on the location and severity of the bleed and may include:
  • Sudden, severe headache
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Seizures
  • Weakness or paralysis on one side of the body
  • Speech problems
  • Vision problems
  • Any other focal neurological defects

ICH Score (maximum score: 6)





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3349, 3351.

questions.text: Where do we see Koenen's tumor?
The most common form of diabetic neuropathy is -
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option 2, which is "Distal symmetric sensory and motor neuropathy" for the most common form of diabetic neuropathy.

Diabetic Distal Symmetric Sensory and Sensorimotor Polyneuropathy (DSPN) DSPN is the most common form of diabetic neuropathy and manifests as sensory loss beginning in the toes that gradually progresses over time up the legs and into the fingers and arms.
 
  • Diabetic neuropathy is a type of nerve damage that can occur in people with diabetes.
  • It is caused by high blood sugar levels, which can damage the nerves throughout the body.
  • Neuropathy can affect any type of nerve in the body, including sensory, motor, and autonomic nerves.
  • Distal symmetric sensory and motor neuropathy is the most common form of diabetic neuropathy. It affects the nerves in the feet, legs, and hands in a symmetrical pattern, meaning that both sides of the body are affected equally.
  • This type of neuropathy can cause numbness, tingling, and pain in the affected areas.
  • It can also lead to muscle weakness and difficulty with coordination and balance.
  • Autonomic neuropathy is another type of diabetic neuropathy that affects the autonomic nerves, which control functions such as heart rate, blood pressure, digestion, and bladder function. Symptoms of autonomic neuropathy can include dizziness, fainting, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, and difficulty with urination. Distal motor neuropathy is a less common form of diabetic neuropathy that affects the nerves that control movement and muscle function.
  • It can cause muscle weakness, muscle wasting, and difficulty with movement and coordination.
Therefore, based on the above explanation, option 2 is the correct answer as it describes the most common form of diabetic neuropathy that affects both sensory and motor nerves in a symmetrical pattern.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3488.

choices.text: Caused by Herpes simplex-2 virus in all cases
Is also referred to as "Benign Recurrent Lymphocytic Meningitis"

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about Mollaret's meningitis except:
questions.solution:
• Mollaret's meningitis is a rare type of meningitis that is characterized by recurrent episodes of meningitis that last for 2-5 days and then resolve spontaneously.
  • The exact cause of Mollaret's meningitis is not fully understood, but it is believed to be caused by the herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2) in some cases.
  • However, it is important to note that not all cases of Mollaret's meningitis are caused by HSV-2. It is caused by other viruses as well like Varicella zoster virus and some non-viral etiologies also.
  • Therefore, option 1 is not completely true about Mollaret's meningitis.

Other options: 
  • Option 2 is true, as Mollaret's meningitis is a recurrent type of meningitis that is generally considered benign, as it does not cause any long-term neurological damage.
  • Option 3 is also true, as Mollaret's meningitis is also known as "Benign Recurrent Lymphocytic Meningitis" due to its recurrent and benign nature and CSF lymphocytosis.
  • Option 4 is  true, as Mollaret's meningitis episodes usually resolve spontaneously without treatment, although antiviral drugs may be used to shorten the duration of symptoms during an episode.
 
  • Therefore, the correct option is 1, as Mollaret's meningitis is NOT ALWAYS caused by HSV-2 only.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1107.

questions.text: Celiac disease has which of the following vitamin deficiencies as uncommon?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4:  Vitamin B12
 
  • Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder that damages the small intestine when gluten is ingested.
  • Gluten is a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye.
  • The damaged small intestine is unable to absorb certain nutrients properly, leading to various deficiencies.
  • In celiac disease, it is uncommon to have a deficiency in Vitamin B12. Vitamin B12 deficiency is more frequently associated with other gastrointestinal disorders that affect the absorption of this vitamin.
  • Vit B12 absorption mainly happens in Ileum, which is unaffected in Celiac disease. Celiac diseases predominantly affects Duodenum followed by jejunum. Jejunum is the principal site of Folate absorption.

The other common vitamin deficiencies associated with celiac disease include:
 
  1. Vitamin D
  2. Folic Acid (Vitamin B9)
  3. Vitamin A



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2460.

questions.text: The effectiveness of ventrolateral cordotomy performed to produce relief of pain from the right leg is because it interrupts the-
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Left Lateral Spinothalamic tract 
 
  • In ventrolateral cordotomy, selected pain-conducting tracts in the spinal cord, i.e. fibers in the lateral spinothalamic pathway, are cut leading to contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation below the level of the lesion.
 
  • In the more recent percutaneous approach, destruction of the lateral spinothalamic at the level of C1-C2 results in a contralateral disruption of painful sensations beyond C4. 

Pain pathway (Lateral Spinothalamic tract):





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 92, 3447.

questions.text: What is the likely cause of Aneurysmal rupture in case of a patient with suspected subarachnoid haemorrhage presents with blood isolated in the fourth ventricle on a CT scan?
questions.solution:
The correct Option is 1: Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery Aneurysm 
 
  • The fourth ventricle is located in the brainstem, and blood isolated in this area on a CT scan indicates bleeding in that region.
  • The Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (PICA) is a branch of the vertebral artery, and aneurysms in this artery can cause subarachnoid hemorrhage with blood isolated in the fourth ventricle.
  • Posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) - the largest branch of vertebral artery. It supplies the lateral part of the medulla, the cerebellar hemisphere, and the choroid plexus of the fourth ventricle.



Vertebral artery branches:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3330, 3354.

questions.text: Below which values of cerebral blood flow Cerebral Ischemia to occur ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: 20 ml / 100 g/ minute 
 
  • The normal CBF is 20 ml/100g/min. This means that 20 milliliters of blood flow through every 100 grams of brain tissue every minute.
  • A decrease in the cerebral blood flow below 20 mL/100 g/min causes reversible ischemia.
  • If this state is prolonged for several hours to days, it can lead to infarction. A decrease in CBF to 0 causes the death of the brain tissue within 4–10 min.

Normal cerebral physiologic values:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3335.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis in case of findings of Basal exudates, infarcts and hydrocephalus observed in brain imaging studies?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Tubercular meningitis 

Tubercular meningitis
  • It is common between 6 months and 4 years of age and usually spread by the hematogenous route.
  • The gelatinous exudate infiltrates the corticomeningeal blood vessels leading to hydrocephalus.

The three stages are-
  1. Prodromal stage
  2. Stage of meningitis
  3. Stage of coma
 
  • CSF study shows reduced sugar level, increased protein level, and lymphocytosis. 
  • Cranial computed tomography (CT) in a case of tubercular meningitis shows basal exudates and hydrocephalus. Intracranial tuberculosis can also manifest as ring-enhancing lesions (tuberculoma), but the basal exudates are the most common and characteristic feature of tubercular meningitis.

Treatment includes antitubercular drugs for 12 months and corticosteroids (to reduce neurologic sequelae).
TB meningitis is the only indication of steroids in TB.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1366.

choices.text: Pleocytosis with low protein and low sugar
Pleocytosis with high protein and low sugar
Lymphocytosis with low protein and low sugar
Lymphocytosis with high protein and low sugar

questions.text: Which of the following CSF findings is associated with Pneumococcal meningitis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Pleocytosis with high protein and low sugar
  • Pneumococcal meningitis is a bacterial infection. The characteristic CSF findings of which are pleocytosis with high protein and low sugar.
  • Other options- Pleocytosis with low protein and low sugar is seen in viral infections.
  • Lymphocytosis is seen in TB and similar conditions.
  • Option 2, i.e. Pleocytosis with high protein and low sugar, is the correct CSF (Cerebrospinal Fluid) finding associated with Pneumococcal meningitis.
  • Pneumococcal meningitis is a type of bacterial meningitis caused by the bacteria Streptococcus pneumoniae.
  • In this condition, the bacteria infect the meninges (the protective membranes that cover the brain and spinal cord) and cause inflammation. This inflammation leads to an increase in the number of white blood cells (WBCs) in the CSF, which is called pleocytosis.
  • Additionally, the bacteria produce toxins that damage the blood-brain barrier, which is a specialized system of cells that regulates the movement of substances between the blood and the brain.
  • This damage leads to an increase in the amount of protein in the CSF, which is called hyperproteinemia.
  • However, the bacteria also consume glucose (sugar) present in the CSF as a source of energy, leading to a decrease in the glucose level, which is called hypoglycorrhachia.
  • This decrease in glucose level is an important diagnostic feature of pneumococcal meningitis and is seen in most cases.
  • Therefore, the correct CSF finding associated with Pneumococcal meningitis is pleocytosis with high protein and low sugar, which is option 2.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 677.

questions.text: Which is an exception to normal pressure spontaneous CSF leaks?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Pseudo tumor Cerebri 
 
  • Normal pressure spontaneous cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leaks: Leak of CSF from the brain or spine into the surrounding tissues.
  • These leaks usually result in a decrease in CSF pressure, leading to conditions like low-pressure headaches when in an upright position.
 
  • Pseudo tumor cerebri (also known as idiopathic intracranial hypertension) refers to a rise in intracranial pressure in the absence of a structural lesion or hydrocephalus.
  • Pseudo tumor cerebri is not associated with CSF leaks or low-pressure headaches and, therefore, is the exception among the provided options.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 116, 224.

questions.text: Increased levels of what are associated with age related dementia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Homocysteine 
 
  • Homocysteine is an amino acid produced when the body breaks down methionine, another amino acid.
 
  • High homocysteine levels are thought to contribute to the development of dementia by promoting oxidative stress, inflammation, and damage to blood vessels, which can impair brain function and increase the risk of neurodegenerative diseases.
 
  • Reducing elevated homocysteine levels through dietary modifications, lifestyle changes, and supplementation with certain B vitamins (such as folate, vitamin B6, and vitamin B12) has been suggested as a potential strategy to mitigate the risk of age-related cognitive decline and dementia.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 191, 194, 3372.

questions.text: Frequency of symptoms in Parkinsonism are shown to have reduced due to deep Brain Stimulation of which part of the brain ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Subthalamic nucleus 
 
  • Deep brain stimulation (DBS) is a neurosurgical procedure that involves implanting electrodes in specific regions of the brain to modulate neural activity and alleviate symptoms of certain neurological disorders.
  • In the case of Parkinsonism, DBS is often used to target the Subthalamic nucleus (STN) or Globus pallidus interna (GPi)
  • The Subthalamic nucleus, part of the brain's basal ganglia, regulates motor control and movement regulation.
  • Deep brain stimulation of the Subthalamic nucleus can modify abnormal neural activity, reducing Parkinsonian symptoms like tremors, rigidity and bradykinesia (slowness of movement).





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3397.

questions.text: To reduce the frequency of Parkinsonism symptoms, which of the following is the most commonly used site for Deep Brain Stimulation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Subthalamic Nucleus 
  • Deep brain stimulation (DBS) is a neurosurgical procedure that involves implanting electrodes in specific regions of the brain to modulate neural activity and alleviate symptoms of certain neurological disorders.
  • In the case of Parkinsonism, DBS is often used to target the Subthalamic nucleus (STN) > Globus pallidus interna (GPi)
  • The Subthalamic nucleus, part of the brain's basal ganglia, regulates motor control and movement regulation.
  • Deep brain stimulation of the Subthalamic nucleus can modify abnormal neural activity, reducing Parkinsonian symptoms like tremors, rigidity and bradykinesia (slowness of movement).





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3397.

questions.text: Experimentally, stimulation of which of the following areas of brain is used to control intractable pain ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Periaqueductal grey matter 
 
  • The periaqueductal gray (PAG) is a small area of gray matter located in the midbrain, near the cerebral aqueduct.
  • Descending pathways from the mesencephalic periaqueductal gray matter inhibit transmission in nociceptive pathways.
  • This descending pathway includes a synapse in the ventromedial medulla (Raphe nucleus) and the release of endogenous opiates. So periaqueductal gray matter releases endogenous opiate, thereby reducing intractable pain.

Other options:
 
  • Mesencephalon, subthalamic nucleus, and medial forebrain bundle, are all structures in the brain that are involved in functions, such as: Movement, cognition, and motivation.
  • However, there is no evidence that stimulation of these structures is effective in controlling pain.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3357.
Sims-Williams, Hugh et al. “Deep brain stimulation of the periaqueductal gray releases endogenous opioids in humans.” NeuroImage vol. 146 (2017): 833-842. doi:10.1016/j.neuroimage.2016.08.038. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5312788/

questions.text: Which of the following areas of the brain is most resistant to Neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Lateral Geniculate Body 
 
  • Neurofibrillary tangles (NFTs) are a hallmark of Alzheimer's disease.
  • NFTs are composed of tau protein, which is normally found in axons, the long fibers that transmit signals between neurons.
  • The Lateral Geniculate Body in the thalamus  is responsible for relaying visual information from the retina to the cortex.
  • It is not as susceptible to NFT formation as other areas of the brain, such as the hippocampus and entorhinal cortex.
  • The Visual Association area (part of the Occipital lobe) is also vulnerable to Neurofibrillary tangle formation in Alzheimer's disease.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3371, 3372.

questions.text: Wernicke's Korsakoff psychosis does not involve which of the following
questions.solution:
• Wernicke's Korsakoff psychosis is a neurological disorder caused by a deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1) in the brain. The disorder is characterized by a range of symptoms, including confusion, memory loss, and difficulty with coordination and movement.
  • The correct option is 4. Hippocampus.
  • The hippocampus is a part of the brain that is involved in the formation and retrieval of memories.
  • Other three options (1. Mamillary body, 2. Thalamus, and 3. Periventricular Grey matter) are all areas of the brain that are affected by Wernicke's Korsakoff psychosis.
  • The mamillary bodies are involved in memory and learning, and damage to these structures can result in amnesia.
  • The thalamus is involved in the processing and relaying of sensory information, and damage to this area can lead to problems with sensory perception.
  • The periventricular grey matter is involved in the regulation of pain and other autonomic functions, and damage to this area can lead to a range of symptoms, including chronic pain and autonomic dysfunction.
 
  • In summary, the correct option is  4. Hippocampus



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3376.
Akhouri S, Kuhn J, Newton EJ. Wernicke-Korsakoff Syndrome. [Updated 2023 Jun 26]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK430729/

questions.text: Which of the following sites is responsible for the amnestic defect in Wernicke's Korsakoff syndrome
questions.solution:
• The thalamus is responsible for the amnestic defect in Wernicke's Korsakoff syndrome.
  • The amnestic defect is a hallmark symptom of Korsakoff's psychosis, which is characterized by severe memory impairment, confabulation, and personality changes.
  • The thalamus is a crucial relay station in the brain that is involved in various functions, including sensory processing, motor control, and memory.
 
  • In Wernicke's Korsakoff syndrome, thiamine deficiency leads to damage to the thalamus, particularly the dorsomedial nucleus, which is responsible for mediating memory function.
  • Damage to the dorsomedial thalamus correlates most closely with the memory loss
  • However, Mammillary body atrophy may also be visible on MRI in the chronic phase
 
  • As a result, patients with Wernicke's Korsakoff syndrome have significant memory impairment, which is a result of damage to the thalamus.
  • Therefore, the most appropriate option is 2. Thalamus > 1. Mamillary body



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3376.
Akhouri S, Kuhn J, Newton EJ. Wernicke-Korsakoff Syndrome. [Updated 2023 Jun 26]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK430729/

questions.text: All of the following conditions cause reduction in conduction velocity of nerve except
questions.solution:
• Acute Motor Axonal Neuropathy (AMAN) is a type of Guillain-Barré syndrome that affects the axons and causes demyelination. This results in a decrease in conduction velocity.
 
  • Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Neuropathy (AIDP) is another type of Guillain-Barré syndrome that affects the myelin sheath and causes demyelination. 
 
  • Hereditary Motor Neuropathy (HSMN) is a genetic disorder that affects the motor nerves and causes muscle weakness and wasting. It does not affect the myelin sheath or the axon diameter, so it does not result in a decrease in conduction velocity.
 
  • Multifocal Motor Neuropathy is a rare disorder that affects the motor nerves and causes muscle weakness and wasting. It is characterized by conduction block, which means that nerve impulses are unable to pass through certain areas of the nerve, resulting in a decrease in conduction velocity.
Therefore, the correct option is 3 :Hereditary Motor Neuropathy (HSMN).



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3502, 3503, 3483, 3507.

questions.text: Except what of the following is not classified as 'Small fiber neuropathies' :
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Vitamin B12 deficiency
 
  • Small fiber neuropathies are a group of disorders that affect the small nerve fibers in the body. These nerves are responsible for transmitting pain, temperature, and touch sensations
 
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause a condition called subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, which can damage the large nerve fibers in the spinal cord (large fiber neuropathy), is responsible for motor function and proprioception.
 
  • A preferential large-fiber sensory loss affecting proprioception and vibration with sparing of small-fiber modalities is present.
 
  • HIV-induced neuropathy, Hansen's disease (leprosy), and Amyloidosis are examples of conditions that can cause small fiber neuropathies.
 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3496.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis in a young adult with proximal weakness of upper limbs and features of facial palsy and winging of scapula.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Facio-Scapulo-Humeral Dystrophy 
 
  • Facioscapulohumeral dystrophy is an autosomal dominant condition that generally presents with asymmetric weakness in facial and shoulder girdle muscles.
  • Occasionally, finger and wrist weakness is the first symptom. 
  • The mouth is rounded and appears puckered because of the protruding lips.
  • Upper facial weakness will manifest as an inability to close the eyes completely in sleep. 
  • Scapular winging is prominent, even in infants. 
  • Eventually, proximal muscles get involved and undergo atrophy, and Gowers sign & Trendelenburg gait appear.
  • Lumbar lordosis, foot drop, and kyphoscoliosis are common complications.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3527.

questions.text: Except what of the following is not associated with 'Episodic' weakness,
All of the following statements about Von-Hippel Lindau syndrome are false except :
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Craniospinal hemangioblastomas are common 
 
  • Von Hippel Lindau (VHL) syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition that arises from a mutation affecting the VHL tumor suppressor gene.
  • Characteristic features of VHL include spinal hemangioblastomas, endolymphatic sac tumor, pheochromocytoma, and cystic lesions of the kidneys, pancreas, and liver.
  • In VHL syndrome, multiple tumors are commonly seen, including hemangioblastomas, clear cell renal cell carcinoma, pheochromocytomas, and pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors.
  • The lesions in VHL syndrome can occur more commonly in infratentorial (below the tentorium) regions of the brain like cerebellum.
  • While tumors involving Schwann cells can be seen in VHL syndrome, they are not among the most common tumors associated with this condition.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2990, 2991.

choices.text: Absent pupillary light reflex and dilated pupils

questions.text: What are the Criteria for Brainstem death?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Absent pupillary light reflex and dilated pupils 

Brainstem death entails testing twice, by two clinicians, to demonstrate the absence of:
  1. Response to pain
  2. Respiratory drive (apnea despite arterial PCO2 ≥ 60 mm Hg )
  3. Pupillary light reflex
  4. Corneal reflex
  5. Vestibulo-ocular reflex
  6. Oculo-cephalic reflex/ Doll’s eye reflex

Other options:
The oculocephalic reflex or doll's eye reflex is used to assess the integrity of the cranial nerves III, VI, and VIII.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 188.

questions.text: Which of the following best suits what is  'AIDS Related Complex'?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Generalized Lymphadenopathy 
 
  • AIDS Related Complex (ARC): Term used in the past to describe an intermediate stage between HIV infection and full-blown AIDS (Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome).
 
  • ARC was characterized by persistent generalized lymphadenopathy, which means enlarged lymph nodes in various regions of the body.
 
  • As the HIV infection progresses, ARC may evolve into full-blown AIDS, where severe immunosuppression leads to AIDS-associated opportunistic infections (Option 2), AIDS-related cancers (Option 3), and severe HIV infection (Option 4).


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1543.

choices.text: It is a cystic swelling in the floor of mouth
It is a type of mucus retention cyst

questions.text: All of the following statements about 'Ranula' are false except:

choices.text: Lining of tall columnar and cuboidal cells

questions.text: What is the difference between a well differentiated follicular carcinoma of thyroid and a follicular adenoma
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Vascular invasion

The key difference between a well-differentiated follicular carcinoma of the thyroid and a follicular adenoma is the presence of vascular invasion.
  • A follicular adenoma is a benign tumor of the thyroid gland that is usually encapsulated and does not invade the surrounding tissues.
  • In contrast, a well-differentiated follicular carcinoma of the thyroid has the potential to invade the surrounding tissues, including blood vessels, which is known as vascular invasion.
  • Vascular invasion is an important diagnostic feature that helps to distinguish between a benign follicular adenoma and a malignant follicular carcinoma.
  • The presence of vascular invasion indicates that the tumor has the potential to spread to other parts of the body, and therefore, it requires aggressive treatment such as surgery, radioactive iodine therapy, and/or external beam radiation therapy.
  • Other features such as Hurtle cell change, lining of tall columnar and cuboidal cells, and nuclear features may also be helpful in distinguishing between a follicular adenoma and a follicular carcinoma, but they are not as reliable as vascular invasion.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 868.

questions.text: Where do we see Multiple Cutaneous sebaceous adenomas

What is the most probable diagnosis if  a thirty year old male presents to the Emergency Department with symptoms of epigastric pain radiating to back that wakes him up at night and is relieved by consuming food. He gives history of similar pain in the past which was diagnosed as perforated duodenal ulcer and treated with omental patch surgery on two occasions. Pain before and after surgery has been controlled with proton pump inhibitors and analgesics.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Duodenal Ulcer 
 
  • The patient's symptoms of epigastric pain that radiates to the back, worsens at night, and is relieved by consuming food suggest a duodenal ulcer.
  • The history of previous perforated duodenal ulcer and omental patch surgery supports the diagnosis of duodenal ulcer.
  • Duodenal ulcers are commonly caused by Helicobacter pylori infection or NSAID use.
  • The characteristic pain associated with duodenal ulcers occurs when the stomach is empty, such as between meals or during the night.
  • Eating food helps neutralize gastric acid and temporarily relieves the pain.
  • The successful control of pain with proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) and analgesics further supports the diagnosis of duodenal ulcer.


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1157.

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common histological subtype
Occult blood in stool is not seen

questions.text: All of the following statements about Gastric carcinoma are false except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Often associated with Hypochlorhydria/Achlorhydria 
 
  • Gastric carcinoma is often associated with hypochlorhydria (reduced stomach acid production) or achlorhydria (absence of stomach acid production).
  • This can be due to chronic inflammation or atrophy of the gastric mucosa.
  • The decrease in acid production can be detected through diagnostic tests such as gastric pH measurement or serum gastrin levels.
Other options:
  • The most common histological subtype is adenocarcinoma, which accounts for the majority of gastric cancer cases.
  • Occult blood in the stool can be a sign of gastrointestinal bleeding, which can occur in gastric carcinoma.
  • Gastric carcinoma is not highly radiosensitive.
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1219.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in a case where a lady presents with three day history of epigastric pain radiating to back. Serum amylase levels were observed to be normal while USG abdomen reveals gall bladder stones and an enlarged pancreas. CT scan was done. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
The etiology of Acute Pancreatitis during pregnancy include gallstone disease or hypertriglyceridemia.
Gallstones are the most common cause of Acute Pancreatitis during pregnancy responsible for more than 70% of cases.


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 1042, 1043.

questions.text: Which of the following is the likely recommended surgical procedure of choice in a case where a fifty year old lady presents with two year history of recurrent abdominal pain with radiation to her back. Pain is severe in intensity and refractory, to simple analgesics. Ultrasound and contrast Enhanced CT scan (CECT) confirmed the diagnosis and showed a dilated pancreatic duct?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4:  Longitudinal Pancreatico jejunostomy 
 
  • In this case of chronic pancreatitis with recurrent attacks, 10 mm dilatation of the pancreatic duct, and intraductal calculi, longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy (also known as Puestow procedure or lateral pancreaticojejunostomy) is the surgery of choice.
  • This procedure involves opening the pancreatic duct along its length and connecting it to a loop of the jejunum, which helps to drain the obstructed pancreatic duct and alleviate pain.


Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1473.

questions.text: A child with H/O stab injury on the anterior abdominal wall presented to ED with omentum protruding from wound. He is otherwise stable. The best course of management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Emergency Laparotomy
 
  • In this scenario, the omentum protruding from the wound indicates an open abdominal injury with potential intra-abdominal organ involvement.
  • Emergency Laparotomy is the appropriate course of action in such cases to assess and address any possible internal injuries and control bleeding if present.
  • Observation, IV fluids, or a wait-and-watch approach are not suitable options in this situation, as there is a risk of significant abdominal organ injury that may require surgical intervention.
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 432.

choices.text: Insertion of abdominal drain followed by laparotomy

questions.text: What should be the next line of management for a patient with abdominal injury presents to the emergency department with signs of peritonitis and shock. Airways and Breathing were secured and IV fluids were started with 2 large bore cannulas?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: FAST
 
  • In a patient with signs of peritonitis and shock, FAST is necessary to assess and address any intra-abdominal injuries.
Exploratory Laparotomy is a surgical procedure that involves making an incision in the abdomen to visually inspect the abdominal organs and identify and treat any injuries or sources of peritonitis.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 378.

questions.text: Which segments have been resected where a surgeon excises a portion of liver to the left of the attachment of the falciform ligament?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Segment 2 and 3 
 
  • When a portion of the liver is excised to the left of the attachment of the falciform ligament, it involves the resection of segments 2 and 3.
  • Segment 2 is located in the left lateral lobe of the liver, while segment 3 is located in the left medial lobe.
  • The falciform ligament separates the liver into left and right lobes, and resecting to the left of its attachment specifically involves segments 2 and 3.
  • Segment 1 refers to the caudate lobe, and segment 4 is located in the right lobe of the liver, so they are not involved in this particular resection.
* Segmental Classification of Liver Lobes:


* Surgical procedures: 





Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1192.

questions.text: Which Renal Calculi is associated with proteus infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Triple phosphate 
 
  • Proteus infection is commonly associated with the formation of struvite stones, which are also called triple phosphate stones.
  • Struvite stones are composed of magnesium ammonium phosphate and are associated with alkaline urine and urinary tract infections, particularly with Proteus species
  • It causes Staghorn calculus. 

Other options:
  • Uric acid stones (option A) are formed due to the precipitation of uric acid in acidic urine.
  • Calcium oxalate stones (option C) are the most common type of kidney stones and can be caused by various factors.
  • Xanthine stones (option D) are rare and typically occur in individuals with an inborn error of purine metabolism.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1474.

questions.text: After TURP, which of the following is the most common cause of delayed urinary obstructive symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Bladder neck stenosis 
 
  • After a transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP), which is a surgical procedure to treat benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), the most common cause of delayed urinary obstructive symptoms is bladder neck stenosis
  • TURP is a surgical procedure performed to treat benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), and it involves removing the obstructing prostate tissue.
  • However, in some cases, scar tissue or fibrosis can develop at the bladder neck, leading to narrowing or stenosis.
  • This can result in urinary flow obstruction and symptoms such as weak urinary stream, difficulty initiating urination, or urinary retention.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1530.

questions.text: During TURP, to prevent injury to which of the following structures does the surgeon dissects above the verumontanum :
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1:  External Urethral Sphincter 
 
  • During TURP, the surgeon dissects above the verumontanum.
  • TURP is a surgical procedure performed to treat benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), and it involves removing the obstructing prostate tissue.
  • The verumontanum is a ridge located in the prostatic urethra. Dissecting above the verumontanum helps prevent injury to the external urethral sphincter.
  • By avoiding injury to the external urethral sphincter, the surgeon minimizes the risk of postoperative urinary incontinence.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1530.

questions.text: Which of the following investigations should be performed to evaluate the suspected diagnosis in case of a 55 year old smoker presented with history of five episodes of macroscopic hematuria each lasting for about 4-5 days in the past five years.?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Urine microscopy and cytology 
 
  • In a case of a 55-year-old smoker with a history of recurrent macroscopic hematuria, the suspected diagnosis is urinary tract malignancy.
  • To evaluate this suspected diagnosis, the recommended investigation is urine microscopy and cytology.
  • Urine microscopy and cytology involve examining the urine sample under a microscope to look for abnormal cells and other indicators of urinary tract malignancy.
  • This investigation helps identify any abnormal cells or evidence of malignancy in the urinary tract.
Ultrasound is a non-invasive and commonly used investigation to evaluate the kidneys, ureters, and bladder, especially to rule out stones or structural abnormalities. However, it may miss small or early-stage bladder tumors and is less sensitive for detecting upper urinary tract malignancies (e.g., renal or ureteral cancers). While useful, it is not definitive for ruling out urothelial malignancies.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1450.

questions.text: Which amongst the following is the best recommended management option for a 40 year old patient with a single kidney presented with a solitary exophytic mass of 4 cm localized at its lower pole.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Partial Nephrectomy 
 
  • For tumors less than or equal to 4 cm in size and limited to the kidney (T1a), partial nephrectomy is performed.
  • Partial nephrectomy is also increasingly being performed in tumors >4cm in size but less than or equal to 7 cms, and limited to the kidney (T1b). If partial nephrectomy is not feasible in T1b tumors, then a radical nephrectomy is done.
  • Other indications for partial nephrectomy are bilateral renal cell carcinoma and carcinoma affecting a solitary functioning kidney.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1483.

questions.text: When the pH of vagina is lowest ?
questions.solution:
#Controversial question
 
  • In normal pregnancy (Option 1) vaginal pH was found to be between 3.8 and 4.0 and is the lowest among other given options.
  • Vaginal pH in Puberty (Option 4) may also fall to 4.
  • So Correct answer should be: Option 1> Option 4
 
  • The vaginal acidity is due to lactic acid which may be present in a variable amount.
  • The pH value is 5.7 in the newborn and reaches 6 to 8 in children, and falls to 4 at Puberty.
  • During pregnancy, the pH value is usually 4.
  • After menopause, the pH rises to 7.
  • The normal pH in healthy women during the child bearing period is above 4.5



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 328.
Riedewald, S et al. “Vaginal and cervical pH in normal pregnancy and pregnancy complicated by preterm labor.” Journal of perinatal medicine vol. 18,3 (1990): 181-6. doi:10.1515/jpme.1990.18.3.181. URL: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/2384841/

questions.text: Vaginal Discharge in an 8 year old Pre-pubertal girl is mainly due to-
questions.solution:
• Vulvovaginitis is an inflammation of the vulva and vaginal tissues . 
  • This is common problem in prepubertal girls. 
  • It is typically not caused by a specific pathogen and is not treated with antibiotics. 
  • It can also be caused by infection, irritation, a  foreign body, allergy, or systemic disease.
  • Physiological leucorrhea is more common in puberty due to hormonal changes.
  • Bacterial vaginosis and sexually transmitted diseases are less likely in pre-pubertal girls.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 333.

questions.text: Where do we see Swiss cheese pattern endometrium -
questions.solution:
Metropathia Haemorrahagia (Schroeder's diseases)
• Seen in women between 40 to 50 years.

questions.text: What is not true about Halban's Disease?
questions.solution:

questions.text: Which of the following is a term used for pain in the right upper quadrant due to adhesions and inflammation between the liver and the diaphragm is
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome 
 
  • Fitz Hugh Curtis syndrome is a sequela of chronic pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), which refers to the inflammation of the liver capsule without the involvement of liver parenchyma.
  • Laparoscopy reveals adhesive bands extending from the fallopian tube on the right side to the undersurface of the liver accounting for the right upper quadrant pain.

* PID pain differentials:

choices.text: Interference with implantation of a fertilized ovum

questions.text: What is not true about the mechanism of action of OCP?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Interference with the placenta formation

Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCPs) function: to prevent ovulation, fertilization, and implantation.
OCPs do not interfere with placenta formation.

OCP MOA:
  • Inhibiting ovulation: OCPs contain hormones that halt monthly egg release, preventing fertilization.
  • Preventing fertilization: OCP hormones cause thick, sticky cervical mucus that hampers sperm movement.
  • Interfering with implantation: OCP hormones thin the uterine lining, deterring fertilized egg attachment.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 576.

questions.text: What is the life span of Cu-380?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: 10 yrs 
 
  • Cu-380 is a copper-containing intrauterine device (IUD) known for its high effectiveness in contraception, with a failure rate of less than 1%.
  • It releases copper ions that incite an inflammatory response in the uterus, hampering sperm survival and fertilization.
  • Its life span extends to 10 years, rendering replacement unnecessary within this time frame.
  • Over the 10-year span, copper within the IUD may degrade, potentially impacting its contraceptive efficacy.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 571.

questions.text: Which contraceptive method use after molar pregnancy is contraindicated/not indicated?
questions.solution:
CuT is not used due to risk of perforation as uterus is friable and use of IUCD can increase risk of bleeding. 

Contraception post Molar Pregnancy
  • Barrier methods until normal Beta -hCG level.
  • Once hCG level have normalised: Combined oral contraceptive (COC) pill may be used.
  • If oral COC was started before the diagnosis of GTD, COC can be continued as its potential to increase risk of GTN is very low
  • IUCD like Cu-T should not be used until  Beta-hCG levels are normal to reduce risk of uterine perforation.

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page no 228.

questions.text: Origin of Carcinoma Cervix mostly corresponds to which common site -
questions.solution:
Option 2 is correct - New Squamocolumnar junction.
 
  • Carcinoma of the cervix is a type of cancer that arises from the cells of the cervix.
  • The cervix is the lower part of the uterus that opens into the vagina. 
  • The squamocolumnar junction (SCJ) is the area where the squamous cells of the ectocervix (outer part of the cervix) meet the columnar cells of the endocervix (inner part of the cervix).
  • This junction is a common site for the development of precancerous and cancerous lesions.
  • However, the origin of carcinoma cervix mostly corresponds to the new squamocolumnar junction (NSCJ), which is formed after menarche (onset of menstruation) and moves towards the external os (opening of the cervix) with age.
  • The NSCJ is the site where the transformation zone (TZ) is located, which is the area where most cervical cancers arise.
Therefore, option 2 - New Squamocolumnar junction - is the correct answer.





Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 409.

questions.text: Sarcoma Botryoides mostly commonly arises from:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Vagina
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma (RMS) is a malignant tumor which arises from embryonic muscle cells.
  • It is the most common soft tissue sarcoma in childhood and young adulthood, and accounts for 4 to 6% of all malignancies in this age group.
  • This tumor presents as a submucosal lesion giving the typical “grape-like” appearance and is usually seen in female infants and young children.
  • Sarcoma botryoides is usually reported as a vaginal tumor in the female reproductive tract of infants.




Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 480.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page no 283.

questions.text: Which of the following procedures has been shown to almost double the rate of successful pregnancy in case of a patient with a large thick walled Hydrosalpinx who is planned for IVF?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Salpingectomy
 
  • Tubal factors account for approximately 25% of cases of infertility, and the most severe manifestation of tubal disease is hydrosalpinx, accounting for 10-30% of tubal diseases.
 
  • Hydrosalpinx is a distension or dilatation of the fallopian tube in the presence of a distal tubal occlusion, and the most common cause is pelvic inflammatory disease. Hydrosalpinx contain embryotoxic fluid which can kill the zygote. 
 
  • Women with hydrosalpinx have lower implantation and pregnancy rates in assisted reproductive technology (ART), due to a combination of mechanical and chemical factors thought to disrupt the endometrial environment.
 
  • Current guidance is removal of the tube by salpingectomy (preferably laparoscopically) before IVF treatment.


Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page no 142, 203.

questions.text: Intracytoplasmic sperm injection is indicated when Total Processed Motile Sperm count is less than:

questions.text: For the prognosis of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH), which of the following is the most important determinant?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Pulmonary Hypertension 

CONGENITAL DIAPHRAGMATIC HERNIA :-
  • They are of 2 types :- BOCHDALEK, MORGAGNI
  • FEATURES :-

-Pulmonary Hypoplasia
-Mediastinal shift
-In severe cases :- Increased risk of birth asphyxia
 
  •  MANAGEMENT :-
-Birth Asphyxia – Start resuscitation ( Avoid bag and mask ventilation )
-First 48 hours – Nasogastric tube to decompress intestine; Mechanical ventilation to expand lungs
-After 48 hours – Surgery
 
  • BAD PROGNOSTIC FACTORS :-
-Pulmonary hypertension
-Liver found in hernia sac in USG

questions.text: Which of the following represents the best management option in a case where a neonate delivered at 38 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 2.2 kg develops intolerance to feed/abdominal distension second day. Physical examination is unremarkable. Sepsis screen is negative. PCV is observed to be 72%?
questions.solution:
• Correct Option is 2: Partial Exchange Transfusion 
  • The given clinical vignette describes the clinical condition called Neonatal Polycythaemia.
  • PCV values of more than 65% indicate Polycythaemia in neonates.
  • Neonatal polycythaemia can be associated with Post-term babies/SGA babies/hypertensive or diabetic mothers/Twin–twin transfusion syndrome (the recipient infant)
  • MANAGEMENT: Symptomatic and/or PCV >75% - Partial Exchange Transfusion, if asymptomatic or PCV<75%  -Fluids/Hydration. 
  • In the clinical stem - the child is symptomatic - so best treatment is PET(Partial Exchange Transfusion).

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 971

questions.text: Infant of diabetics mother with weight 3.8 kg presented with seizures after 16 hours of birth. Which of the following is the most likely cause?

The given clinical scenario is a baby with macrosomia due to diabetes in mother.

  • Intraventricular haemorrhage is commonly seen in premature babies
  • Hypoglycaemia in neonates born to diabetic mothers , being a very common condition is thus the most appropriate answer to this question.

questions.text: In pentology of Fallot, which of the following represents the additional component:

questions.text: Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) can be differentiated from Atrial septal Defect (ASD) by which of the following features on an X-ray chest?
questions.solution:
The correct Option is 1:  Enlarged Left Atrium.
  • In VSD, blood flows from the left ventricle to the right ventricle. From the right ventricle, blood flows through the pulmonary artery into the lungs leading to increased pulmonary blood flow and the development of Pulmonary plethora.
  • The large volume of blood finally reaches the left atrium contributing to its increased size. Thus left atrium is enlarged.

Reference:https://radiopaedia.org/articles/pentalogy-of-fallot

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in a previously healthy infant presenting with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain? The mother says that the child has been passing altered jelly like consistency stool after episodes of pain, but gives no history of vomiting or bleeding per rectum.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Intussusception 

The history given in the clinical vignette is of recurrent episodes of abdominal pain and passage of altered jelly like consistency stools best matches with Intussusception. Intussusception is characterised by telescoping of one intestinal segment into another which results in mesenteric ischaemia and damage to the blood vessels/gut epithelia. This sloughed off epithelium mixed with blood gives the stool its jelly like consistency along with red colour resulting in the characteristic red currant jelly like stools.

Other Options
Option 1: Rectal Polyps – Characterised by painless bleeding per rectum and no colicky abdominal pain. 

Option 3: Necrotizing Enterocolitis – It occurs due to immaturity of the gut in preterms. Characterised by abdominal distension, decreased bowel sounds, Pneumatosis intestinalis, Pneumatosis portalis, Pneumoperitoneum, Peritonitis.

Option 4: Meckel Diverticulum – Characterised by features like haematochezia/ melena, right lower quadrant pain and does not have stools with jelly like consistency. 



Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 283

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis in case of a 12 year old boy who is presented with hematemesis, Malena and mild splenomegaly? There is no obvious jaundice.
questions.solution:
• Clinical condition typically presents in children with portal hypertension due to obstruction of the portal vein outside the liver.
  • It often results in hematemesis (due to esophageal varices), splenomegaly, and normal liver function (no jaundice), making this the most likely diagnosis.

  • Non-Cirrhotic Portal Fibrosis (NCPF): This is also a cause of portal hypertension with splenomegaly and hematemesis, but it is more common in adults and would likely present with features such as ascites or liver dysfunction, which are not seen here.

  • Cirrhosis: Typically presents with signs of liver dysfunction such as jaundice, ascites, and potentially splenomegaly, along with portal hypertension. The absence of jaundice  in this patient makes cirrhosis less likely.

  • Malaria with DIC: Malaria can cause splenomegaly, but the absence of fever, jaundice, or signs of hemolysis makes malaria with DIC an unlikely diagnosis.



    Reference:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4455142/

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis in a child who is presented to the emergency department with fever and mild respiratory distress. questions.text: The most common tumour associated with Neurofibromatosis-I (NF-1) in a child is-

  • While other malignancies may also be seen in NF-1 patients, JMML is the one most commonly associated with the condition.

questions.text: Meningitis in children is most commonly caused by:

questions.text: Which of the following hormones should be replaced first in the case of a six-year-old child managed by complete surgical removal of craniopharyngioma and now has developed multiple endocrinopathies?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Hydrocortisone 

Complete surgical removal of Craniopharyngioma leads to the development of Pan hypopituitarism.
  • This leads to reduced production of pituitary hormones ultimately causing multiple endocrinopathies.
  • Of these the most dangerous outcome is the development of secondary adrenal insufficiency due to reduced production of ACTH from the pituitary gland.
  • Hence the first hormone that should be replaced is Hydrocortisone in order to prevent the development of secondary adrenal insufficiency. Thyroxine is replaced in the end because thyroxine supplementation increases BMR and it leads to consumption of other hormones if replaced earlier and deficiencies of other hormones could occur. 
 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2884,2676,2677

questions.text: Inability to hear high frequency sounds indicates damage to which of the following regions ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Basilar membrane near Oval Window 

Basilar membrane near oval window carries high-frequency sounds. High frequencies are taken up by the basal turn of the cochlea and lower frequencies by the apex. Spiral ganglion conducts sound from the inner ear to the brainstem. Stria vascularis secretes the endolymph. Helicotrema is the opening where scala tympani and scala vestibuli communicate.
Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 39

questions.text: Which of the following types of Tympanoplasty is being referred by Sound Baffle Operation ?

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? in case of an athletic teenage girl complains of anterior knee pain on climbing stairs and on getting up after prolonged sitting?
questions.solution:
• Chondromalacia Patellae is a condition where the cartilage on the undersurface of the patella (kneecap) becomes soft, frayed and damaged, leading to pain in the front of the knee.
  • This condition is commonly seen in young athletes, especially females, who engage in activities that involve repetitive bending of the knee such as running, jumping, or squatting.
  • The pain is usually worse when going up and down stairs or after prolonged sitting with the knee in bent position.
  • Treatment for chondromalacia patellae typically involves rest, physical therapy, and pain management, and in severe cases, surgery may be necessary.
  • Plica syndrome-When a fold in the synovial tissue (plica) becomes irritated and inflamed.It is caused by repetitive knee movements. Clinical features include pain at rest infront and inner side of knee.

questions.text: A six year old boy presented to the emergency department with a painful limb. Clinical examination reveals tenderness in the femoral triangle and some limitation of hip movements. An X-ray was done which was normal. What is the likely next course of action?

questions.text: Which of these agents do not decrease bone resorption in osteoporosis?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, teriparatide does not cause bone resorption. It is a synthetic analogue of PTH which causes bone formation. 
  • Out of the options provided, Alendronate, Etidronate, and Gallium nitrate are all agents that decrease bone resorption in osteoporosis.
  • Alendronate and Etidronate belong to a class of drugs called bisphosphonates, which work by inhibiting the activity of osteoclasts, the cells responsible for bone resorption. 
  • Teriparatide, on the other hand, is a recombinant form of parathyroid hormone (PTH) that increases bone formation by stimulating the activity of osteoblasts, the cells responsible for bone formation. It does not directly decrease bone resorption, but rather works by increasing bone formation more than bone resorption, resulting in a net gain in bone mass.
Therefore, the correct option is 4. Teriparatide, as it does not directly decrease bone resorption in osteoporosis.


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 309,310

questions.text: Which of the following is not a yoke muscles ?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Right inferior rectus and left inferior oblique.
 
  • The concept of yoke muscles in ocular movements refers to the pairs of muscles that work together to move the eyes in a coordinated manner.
  • The right inferior rectus muscle primarily depresses, adducts, and extorts the eye, while the left inferior oblique muscle primarily elevates, abducts, and intorts the eye. These muscles do not function as yoke muscles since their primary actions are in different directions.
