questions.text: Which of these is a cause of Angular conjunctivitis ?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Moraxella.
 
  • Angular conjunctivitis is a chronic type of conjunctivitis characterized by mild inflammation limited to the conjunctiva and the lid margins near the angles. It is often accompanied by maceration of the surrounding skin.
  • The most common causative organism is Moraxella axenfield/ lacunata, which is responsible for the characteristic appearance of bacilli placed end to end, leading to the alternative name of diplobacillary conjunctivitis.
  • The source of infection is typically the nasal tract of healthy individuals or the nasal discharge of patients with angular conjunctivitis. The infection spreads from the nasal cavity to the eye through contaminated hands or handkerchiefs.

questions.text: Histologically, Pineguecula is best characterized by-
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Elastotic degeneration 
 
  • Pinguecula is a common non-cancerous growth of the conjunctiva, typically located on the nasal side of the eye, adjacent to the cornea.
  • It is an elevated, horizontally oriented areas of bulbar conjunctival thickening that are white to yellow in color and adjoin the limbus in the palpebral fissure area.

Histopathologically, pingueculae are characterized by: 
 
  • Elastotic degeneration of the collagen
  • Hyalinization of the conjunctival stroma
  • Collection of basophilic elastotic fibers
  • Granular deposit
  • Non involvement of the cornea


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 206.

questions.text: What do Negative Jones-1 and Jones -II Dye test indicate?
questions.solution:
Jones I test:
Differentiates partial obstruction from hypersecretion of tears.
Fluorescein 2% drops instilled into the conjunctiva.
After 5 minutes cotton tipped applicator inserted under the inferior turbinate.
Positive: Detection of fluorescein from nose means patency of the system.
Negative: No dye detected, means either partial or absolute obstruction or failure of lacrimal pump.

Jones II test:
The residual fluorescence is flushed from the conjunctival sac following an negative jones I test.
Clear saline is placed into the inferior canaliculus using syringe/cannula.
Irrigant is retrieved from nasal cavity.
Positive: Recovery of dye stained saline from the nose meaning a partial obstruction of the NLD.
Negative: Recovery of unstained saline through the nose means total obstruction of the upper drainage system or a defective lacrimal pump mechanism.




Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 427, 428.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the genetics of Retinoblastoma is not true?
questions.solution:
Incorrect option is 3: Hereditary retinoblastoma accounts for 90 percent of all cases.
 
  • Retinoblastoma is a malignant proliferation of immature retinal neural cells and is the most common intraocular malignancy in children. 
  • It is associated with mutations in the RB1 gene, which is a tumor suppressor gene (option 1) at chromosome 13q14 (option 2).
  • It is a tumour of a group called small round blue cell tumours because the immature retinal neural cells are seen as small round cells with large nuclei. 
  • Hereditary retinoblastoma accounts for approximately 10 percent of all cases (option 3 and 4). The majority of retinoblastoma cases (about 90 percent) are non-hereditary and occur sporadical.


Reference: Essential Paediatrics by OP Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 607.

  • The lens vesicle then differentiates to form the lens of the eye.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in case of a child presented with lid lag and an enlarged cornea with a diameter of 13 mm. Examination of the eye revealed double contoured opacities concentric to the limbus.
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Congenital Glaucoma.
 
  • Normal infant cornea measures 10.5 mm. A diameter of >13 mm confirms corneal enlargement in congenital glaucoma.
  • Primary congenital glaucoma refers to abnormally high intraocular pressure (IOP), which occurs as a result of a developmental anomaly of the angle of the anterior chamber. Onset is usually less than 3 years of age.
  • Trabeculodysgenesis (defective trabecular meshwork) is the mechanism of raised IOP, simulating open-angle glaucoma. The CYP1B1 gene is implicated in the pathogenesis of congenital glaucoma. It is not associated with any other ocular or systemic anomaly. 
  • Lacrimation, photophobia, and blepharospasm form the classic triad of symptoms of congenital glaucoma.
Signs seen in congenital glaucoma:

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis in case of a 75-year-old patient presented with deterioration of vision. On examination, the pupillary reflex is observed to be sluggish and Intraocular pressure was normal. Optic disc evaluation showed a large and deep cup and primarily showed paracentral scotomas :
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Normal Tension Glaucoma  (NTG)
NTG refers to Optic disc changes and visual field defects of Glaucoma without any rise in IOP.
 
  • The impact of NTG can range from non-progressive, asymptomatic disease to bilateral blindness. A variety of mechanisms have been proposed to explain the pathogenesis of NTG. Whereas IOP is the main driver of progressive visual loss in most patients with POAG, NTG likely represents a heterogeneous or multifactorial group of etiologies, with a common final pathway of retinal ganglion cell loss. Genetics is known to play a role because of the strong association with family history .
Pathophysiology:
  • The histopathological changes in NTG are the same as those found in POAG, namely loss of retinal ganglion cell axons (retinal nerve fiber layer - RNFL) and glial tissue at the optic nerve head, leading to optic disc excavation and cupping.Typically, RNFL loss is more common in the supero- and inferotemporal neuroretinal bundles, leading to notches, but loss may also be global and concentric. Some changes are more common in NTG compared with POAG. These include optic disc hemorrhages and temporal RNFL defects, with localized, deep paracentral scotomas, more often in the superior hemifield.
  • Because the IOP is normal, suspicion will usually be roused by optic disc appearance or a visual field defect on automated perimetry. If the presentation is advanced, patients may have symptoms of reduced vision, difficulty with low contrast situations, and awareness of visual field defects.
  • Optic disc hemorrhages are more common in NTG than POAG.
  • Corneal pachymetry is used to measure the central corneal thickness (CCT). Reduced CCT is associated with progression risk. Thinner corneas are associated with the underestimation of intraocular pressure using applanation tonometry.




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1061, 1062.

questions.text: Retinoblastoma is most commonly spread by -
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Optic Nerve.
 
  • Retinoblastoma is a malignant proliferation of immature retinal neural cells and is the most common intraocular malignancy in children. 
  • It is associated with mutations in the RB1 gene, which is a tumor suppressor gene at chromosome 13q14.
  • In the stage of extraocular extension, the globe bursts through the sclera, usually near the limbus or near the optic disc (from where it spreads most commonly). 
  • This is followed by rapid fungation and involvement of extraocular tissues results in marked proptosis. 
  • Distant metastasis occurs through the lymphatic spread and the direct extension by continuity to the optic nerve and brain.

questions.text: What is Central Retinal artery occlusion known to be associated with?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Orbital mucormycosis > 2. Diabetic Retinopathy (#controversial)(Option 2 as better answer has been confirmed by faculty from AIIMS,Delhi)
 
  • Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO) is known to be associated with Orbital mucormycosis.
  • CRAO is sight-threatening emergency caused by a sudden blockage of the central retinal artery, leading to ischemia of the retina. It is commonly associated with embolism, infections and vasculitis. Inflammation in the form of vasculitis or infection (e.g., varicella or mucor infection), optic neuritis, or even orbital disease (e.g., mucormycosis) may cause central retinal artery obstruction.
  • Orbital mucormycosis is a rare but serious fungal infection caused by the rhizopus species.
  • Rhizopus is knownn be to be angio-invasive- can lead to the invasion of blood vessels, including the central retinal artery, resulting in CRAO and subsequent loss of blood supply to the retina 
Other risk factors for CRAO include:
  • Heart disease
  • Carotid artery disease
  • Varicella infection
  • Radiation exposure
  • Trauma
Note: Uncontrolled diabetes is known to be associated with CRVO but not CRAO. Diabtetic Retinopathy is an MICRO-angiopathy - hence will affect small vessels and does NOT lead to occlusion in bigger vessel like Central retinal artery. Infection and embolus are more common - hence, Orbital mucormycosis is a better answer.
 

Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 520.

questions.text: Maximum sedation is caused by which of the following anticholinergic premedications?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Scopolamine 
 
  • Among the given anticholinergic premedications, scopolamine is known to cause maximum sedation.
  • This is because scopolamine has a higher affinity for muscarinic receptors than atropine and Glycopyrrolate.
  • It blocks the effects of acetylcholine, a neurotransmitter that is involved in a variety of functions, including heart rate, salivation, and sweating.
  • Thus scopolamine is also used in nacro-analysis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Low blood: gas partition co-efficient 
 
  • The blood: gas partition coefficient is a measure of how easily a gas dissolves in blood.
  •  A low blood: gas partition coefficient means that the gas will dissolve less easily in blood than in air. This means that the gas will have a faster onset of action, as it will be able to pass from the lungs to the brain more quickly.
  • A high blood: gas partition coefficient (Option A) means that the gas will dissolve more easily in blood than in air. This means that the gas will have a slower onset of action, as it will take longer for the gas to pass from the lungs to the brain.
  • So, the property that will lead to a rapid onset of action of an inhalation agent is a low blood:gas partition coefficient.





Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 403.

questions.text: Which is an exception to mandatory steps of Traditional Rapid Sequence induction?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. IV adrenaline
 
  • Traditional Rapid Sequence Induction (RSI) is a technique used to rapidly induce anesthesia while minimizing the risk of aspiration of gastric contents like pregnancy, obstruction. 
  • Order: Preoxygenation with 100% oxygen -> Administer IV induction agent -> IV succinylcholine -> Do not ventilate -> Direct laryngoscopy and intubation -> Confirm endotracheal tube placement -> Remove cricoid pressure.



Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1382, 1383.

questions.text: In which of the following is Ketamine the preferred anesthetic agent ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Bronchial asthma 
 
  • Ketamine is indeed the preferred anesthetic agent in cases of bronchial asthma.
  • Ketamine is a dissociative anesthetic that provides analgesia, sedation, and anesthesia while maintaining respiratory function.
  • It has bronchodilator effects, which means that it can help to open up the airways and make it easier for patients to breathe.
  • Ketamine's sympathomimetic effects can help maintain bronchial smooth muscle tone and minimize bronchospasm during induction and maintenance of anesthesia.
* [Extra Edge]: Choice of Anesthesics


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 411.

questions.text: Identify the statement which is true about 'Gregg' effect:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Increased coronary flow improves LV systolic performance 
 
  • Gregg effect: Increased coronary flow improves LV (left ventricular) systolic performance by enhancing oxygen and nutrient delivery to the heart muscle, aiding better contraction and preventing heart failure.
Treatment options to increase coronary blood flow:
  • Angioplasty: Opens narrowed/blocked coronary arteries.
  • Stent placement: Keeps coronary arteries open after angioplasty.
  • Coronary artery bypass grafting: Creates a new blood supply to the heart.



Reference: Salavastru, C I, and R Cârmaciu. “The role of the Gregg phenomenon in cardiac performance.” Romanian journal of physiology : physiological sciences vol. 35,3-4 (1998): 253-7. URL: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11061325/

questions.text: Identify the statement which is incorrect regarding contrast in radiography:
questions.solution:
• In a solution ionic monomers breakup into their anion and cation components delivering 3 iodine atoms (3:2 ratio of iodine to osmolar particles)
  • Osmolar contrast agents may be ionic or non-ionic.
  • Osmolality refers to the concentration of particles in a solution, while ionicity refers to the presence or absence of charged particles in a solution.
  • Osmolar contrast agents can be further classified into high osmolar and low osmolar agents. 
  • Iohexol is a low osmolar contrast media, not high osmolar as mentioned in option 4.
  • Gadolinium is an example of a non-ionic contrast agent that can cross the blood-brain barrier, as mentioned in option 3.
  • Therefore, option 4 is the incorrect statement.



Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 6th edition, Page no 28, 44.

questions.text: In a patient with decreased renal function to avoid contrast nephropathy, which of the following contrast agents is preferred:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Low osmolar contrast.

All iodinated contrast media are nephrotoxic. High osmolar are more nephrotoxic whereas low osmolar are less nephrotoxic. 

Diagnostic criteria for contrast induced nephropathy:
 
Impairment of renal function measured as :
  • 25% increase in serum creatinine from baseline or
  • 0.5 mg/dl increase in absolute serum creatinine value 
  • Within 48-72 hours after intravenous contrast administration. 
Risk factors- Elderly age, DM, CKD, hypovolemia, multiple myeloma

Treatment- Hemodialysis 

Prevention:
  • Most important step is pre-contrast hydration using normal saline. 
  • High dose statins
  • N-Acetyl Cysteine
  • Vitamin C
Renal function usually reverts to normal within 7-14 days provided good supportive care is administered and co-morbidities are managed.



Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 734.
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2300.
Modi K, Padala SA, Gupta M. Contrast-Induced Nephropathy. [Updated 2023 Jul 24]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK448066/

questions.text: In a chest radiograph, which is the objective sign of identifying pulmonary hypertension?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Diameter of descending right pulmonary artery > 16 mm ( Fact based )
1. Enlarged Pulmonary Arteries:
   - The central pulmonary arteries, particularly the right pulmonary artery, may be enlarged. This is often seen as an increased diameter of the right descending pulmonary artery greater than 16 mm.

2. Pruning of Peripheral Pulmonary Vessels:
   - There may be a reduction in the size and number of peripheral pulmonary vessels (known as "pruning"), which reflects a decreased blood flow to the lung periphery.

3. Right Ventricular Enlargement:
   - The right ventricle may become enlarged due to increased pressure load, leading to a shift of the cardiac silhouette. This can cause a rounded or "boot-shaped" appearance of the heart and an elevated cardiac apex.

4. Enlarged Right Atrium:
   - The right atrium may also become enlarged, which can be seen as a prominent right heart border.

5. Prominent Main Pulmonary Artery:
   - The main pulmonary artery may appear prominent and bulbous, often seen as an increased convexity at the left upper heart border



Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 403.

questions.text: Which of the following investigation given below is best for diagnosing bone metastasis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Bone scan.
 
  • Most sensitive routine imaging modality to detect bony metastasis. 
  • Able to identify both sclerotic and lytic lesions. 
  • In majority of cases, they demonstrate increased uptake-hot spot.
  • Occasionally, in very aggressive purely lytic lesions, a cold spot may be seen. 
Superscan-
  • Imaging appearance on Tc-99m diphosphonate bone scan due to high ratio of bone to soft tissue tracer accumulation. 
  • Intense osteoblastic activity of bones causes diminished renal and background soft tissue uptake.




Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 974, 975, 1046.

questions.text: In which of the clinical scenario given below is Tomography (CT scan) is least accurate for diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Gallstones.
 
  • On CT, majority of cholesterol stones appear hypodense as compared to bile whereas some of the gallstones are isodense to bile. This makes its identification on a CT scan difficult. 
  • Only calcified gallbladder stones are hyperdense as compared to bile, making them the only type to be clearly visualized on CT scan images. 
Ultrasound is considered the gold standard for detecting gallstones:
 
  • Greyscale ultrasound
    • Echogenic focus within gallbladder lumen with prominent posterior acoustic shadowing regardless of pathological type 
    • Gravity-dependent movement with change of patient position ( rolling stone sign)
  • Color Doppler
    • Demonstrates twinkling artifact and is particularly useful for identification of small stones


Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 659, 660.

questions.text:
Which of the following is the dose of Radiation during whole-body exposure that leads to
Hematological syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is 1: 2Gy.

Acute radiation syndrome can be divided into 4 stages:


 
  • Hematological system:
    • First system to get involved due to maximum proportion of undifferentiated cells. These cells are highly sensitive to effects of radiation.
    • Threshold dose is 1-2 Gray. 
    • Primary cause of death-infection/hemorrhage
    • Death occurs within few months after exposure. 
 
  • Gastrointestinal system:
    • Second organ system to get affected. 
    • Threshold dose is 6-10 Gray. 
    • Characterized by malaise, severe diarrhea and electrolyte imbalances. 
    • Death occurs within 2 weeks and survival is less likely. 
 
  • Cardiovascular/CNS: 
    • Last system to get involved 
    • Threshold dose of ~ 20 Gray.
    • Death occurs due to collapse of circulatory system and raised intracranial tension secondary to edema, vasculitis and meningitis.
    • Death occurs within 3 days of exposure. 


Reference: Rosen's Emergency Medicine: Concepts and Clinical Practice, 9th edition, Page no 1807.

Identify the drug which is a 'Radioprotective' Agent.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Amifostine.

Radioprotectors are compounds which trap free electrons in tissues making them unavailable for further chemical reactions that lead to cellular damage. 

Examples include: 
  • Cysteine
  • Amifostine (Does not cross blood brain barrier, hence no radioprotective role in CNS)
  • GM-CSF
  • Pentoxifylline 
  • Zinc Oxide 
Examples of radiosensitizers-
  • most potent- oxygen
  • 5 Flurouracil
  • Gemcitabine


Reference: Basic Radiotherapy Physics and Biology, 2nd edition (2014), Page no 295.
Wasserman, T H, and D M Brizel. “The role of amifostine as a radioprotector.” Oncology (Williston Park, N.Y.) vol. 15,10 (2001): 1349-54; discussion 1357-60. URL: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11702962/

choices.text: Neuropsychological sequelae are independent of radiation dose

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about long-term sequelae of Craniospinal Radiotherapy for children with CNS tumors?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Neuropsychological sequalae are independent of radiation dose. Rest of the above statements are correct. 
  • Neuropsychological sequelae are dependent of radiation dose.
  • Following higher radiation doses given for brain tumours, an increased risk of learning and behaviour difficulties is seen.
  • An important risk factor for the incidence and severity of neuropsychological long term effects is the age at diagnosis.
  • Other factors include the impact of direct and indirect tumour-related parameters, treatment parameters with neuropsychological long-term effects worse for whole brain compared with partial brain irradiation, concomitant use of some chemotherapeutic agents, premorbid patient characteristics, such as intelligence, and the quality of ‘catch up’ education.


Reference: Walter & Miller's Textbook of Radiotherapy, 7th edition, Page no 587, 588.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a disorder of Perception?
questions.solution:
• Illusion: Illusions are unique perceptual experiences in which information derived from "real" external stimuli results in a false perception of the thing or thing that is being stimulated.
  • Hallucination: A hallucination is a false perception of objects or events involving your senses: sight, sound, smell, touch and taste in the absence of an external stimulus
  • Delusion: Delusion is a disorder of content of thought. Its a misguided opinion/False Belief that is maintained in the face of overwhelming evidence to the contrary.
  • Depersonalization Disorder: When you have the sensation that you are looking at yourself from outside of your body, that things around you aren't real, or both, you have depersonalization-derealization disorder.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 202.

questions.text: Name the phenomenon where a a 25 year old women suddenly collapsed on hearing a bad news.
Identify Delusional misidentification syndrome from the following-
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: CAPGRAS SYNDROME

CAPGRAS and FREGOLI are examples of Delusional Misidentification Syndrome.
A few important points, terms and syndromes to remember about Delusion:-
  • Timeline- More than or equal to 1 month
  • It’s a fixed, firm and false belief.
  • Apart from that particular delusion all order fields of life and functioning remains unaffected. ( VVV IMP)
  • Most common delusion - Delusion of Persecution
  • FOLIE A DEUX - Shared delusion where a person develops delusion after staying around a person having delusion.
  • DECLEREMBAUT SYNDROME - Erotomania [Imp clinical scenario frequently tested - The person generally a woman feels that the celebrity or a person of higher social profile loves her.]
  • OTHELLO SYNDROME
  • COTARD SYNDROME - Nihilistic Delusion-[Imp clinical scenario frequently tested- The person feels that his intestines are rotting and the world is ending.]
  • EKBOM SYNDROME – Delusional Parasitosis – Person constantly feels that he is infested with parasites.
  • CAPGRAS - FAMILY SEEMS LIKE STRANGER
  • FREGOLI- STRANGER SEEMS LIKE FAMILY
[CAPGRAS- FREGOLI: TRICK TO REMEMBER - A person cannot recognize his family members once they start wearing caps - CAPGRAS]


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 319, 321.

questions.text: In which of the following Clusters is Schizoid Personality classified?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: CLUSTER A
  •  A few important points to remember about PERSONALITY DISORDERS are:-
 Personality Disorders are pervasive patterns of behaviors which cause severe distress and impaired functioning. They are ego syntonic ie the person is usually not aware of his problems. They usually appear by early adulthood.


A FEW MNEMONICS AND TRICKS TO REMEMBER:-
  • A - ODD, ECCENTRIC ----{ vowels stick together - A E O } --- To remember the different personalities under CLUSTER A - PASS - Paranoid, Schizoid, Schizotypal
  • B- DRAMATIC, WILD
  • C- ANXIOUS


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 746-750.

questions.text: Which is an exception to Bleuler's criteria for schizophrenia ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: AUTOMATISM

The BLEULER’S CRITERIA for Schizophrenia includes the following :- (4A)
  1. Autism
  2. Ambivalence
  3. Association disturbance
  4. Affect problems
 
  • Automatism is not a part of Bleuler's criteria for schizophrenia.
  • Automatism refers to the performance of actions without conscious thought or intention, and is not related to the core symptoms of schizophrenia.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 300.
